name: Dmitry Sautin
description: With seven Olympic medals, Dmitry Sautin has won more Olympic medals than any other diver. Representing the Unified Team (Équipe Unifié) in 1992, he earned a bronze on the springboard. In 1996, he was the gold medalist on the platform, representing Russia. The addition of synchronized events in 2000 allowed Sautin to enter four diving events in Sydney and he won medals in all four events, topped by a gold medal in the synchronized platform event. Sautin won his seventh Olympic medal, a bronze, in 2004 on the springboard. Sautin was also world champion on the springboard in 1998 and the platform in 1994 and 1998, and European champion on the springboard in 1995 and 1997 and the platform in 1993.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (12–4–2 1991 Athina DIV silver: platform (competed for the Soviet Union); 1993 Sheffield DIV gold: platform, silver: 3 m springboard (competed for Russia); 1995 Wien DIV gold: 3 m springboard and platform (competed for Russia); 1997 Sevilla DIV gold: 3 m springboard (competed for Russia); 1999 İstanbul DIV gold: platform (competed for Russia); 2000 Helsinki DIV gold: 3 m springboard, platform, and synchronized platform, silver: synchronized springboard (competed for Russia); 2002 Berlin DIV gold: 3 m springboard and synchronized springboard (competed for Russia); 2006 Budapest DIV gold: 3 m springboard, silver: synchronized springboard (competed for Russia); 2008 Eindhoven DIV gold: 3 m springboard and synchronized springboard (competed for Russia); 2010 Budapest DIV bronze: synchronized springboard (competed for Russia)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Aquatics Championships (5–1–3 1994 Roma DIV gold: platform, silver: 3 m springboard (competed for Russia); 1998 Perth DIV gold: 3 m springboard and platform (competed for Russia); 2001 Fukuoka DIV gold: 3 m springboard, bronze: synchronized springboard (competed for Russia); 2003 Barcelona DIV gold: synchronized springboard, bronze: 3 m springboard (competed for Russia); 2007 Melbourne DIV bronze: 3 m springboard (competed for Russia))

name: Sadiq Abdullahi
description: Dr. Sadiq Abubakar Abdullahi was a Nigerian tennis player and professor. Abdullahi played tennis from 1983 to 1989, achieving his highest singles ranking of 262 in the world in October 1985. Abdullahi’s first involvement with tennis was when he was 10. Abdullahi would climb over the fence of the Lagos Lawn Tennis Club and earn money by picking up the balls. His father did not approve, as it impacted on his son’s early education, but he eventually went on to graduate from Kufena College. Abdullahi won the Nigerian National Championships on three consecutive occasions (1986–88). In 1987, Abdullahi defeated Tony Mmoh, the Nigerian number-two-seed, at the Kenya Open ATP Challenger. The following year he reached the semi-finals of the Okada Challenger tournament in Kenya, losing to fellow countryman Nduka Odizor. Abdullahi competed in the singles tournament at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, losing to Javier Sánchez Vicario of Spain in the opening round. Abdullahi retired from playing tennis in 1989 and joined the management company Peter Burwash International. Abdullahi went to the Doral Resort and Country in Miami where Arthur Ashe was the international tennis director. Abdullahi was the head of coaching and worked closely with Ashe until his death in 1993. Afterwards he stopped his tennis coaching to become a teacher and educator. Abdullahi became a professor and taught in the Department of Teaching and Learning at Florida International University. After setting up the Nigerian Tennis Foundation in 2008, Abdullahi co-founded Tennis Vision 2035, an organisation for young athletes.

name: Renate Boy-Garisch-Culmberger
description: Renate Boy was born in East Prussia as Garisch-Culmberger and was dispersed to Thuringia during World War II, and from there to Rügen. The name of her noble family was originally from Alsace and was called Garisch von Culmberger. Renate Boy later married East German wrestler Nils Boy. She started at the 1960 (finishing sixth) and 1964 (silver medal) Olympics under her maiden name for the combined German team and in 1968 (placing fifth) under the name of her husband for the East German team. She was in 1961 the first German woman to put the shot over 17 meters (17.18). By profession she was an educated goods dispatcher and later a shift forewoman in a fish combine at Rostock. In her youth she was an avid handball player. At the European Championships she won a shot put silver medal in 1962 and placed fifth seven years later. She also became East German Champion in 1961-65 and 1967, and was indoor champion in 1964 and 1965. In 1964 she set her lone world record putting the shot to 17.19 in an indoor competition. Her trainers were Emil Hirschfeld and then Karl-Heinz Bauersfeld. Personal Best: SP – 17.87 (1969).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (0–1–0 1962 Beograd silver: shot put (competed as Renate Garisch for Germany))

name: Mary Koboldt
description: Mary Koboldt played hockey as a midfielder for the University of Iowa from 1982-85. She was named three times to the All-Big Ten team, and was a two-time All-American. She also led Iowa to the NCAA tournament all four years she played, and led them to two Big Ten Championships. As a senior she was named All-Big Ten Offensive Player of the Year and was a nominee for the Honda Broderick Award, as the top collegiate female athlete in the country. Koboldt twice played for the US National team, including her 1988 Seoul Olympic appearance. She is a member of the National Iowa Varsity Club and the University of Iowa Athletics Hall of Fame. She later coached youth leagues and worked as a sales rep for a major pharmaceutical company in St. Louis
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1987 Indianapolis HOK silver)

name: Angelo Ferrario
description: Angelo Ferrario finished fourth with the 4×400 metres relay team (with Giacomo Carlini, Ettore Tavernari, and the non-Olympian Mario Rabaglino) at the 1934 European Championships. At the 1938 European Championships Ferrario finished fifth with the 4×400 metres relay team (with Otello Spampani, Mario Lanzi, and the non-Olympian Gioacchino Dorascenzi). Personal Best: 400 – 49.3 (1934).

name: Niels Rohweder
description: Niels Rohweder studied at the København (Copenhagen) Academy of Art from 1924-32 with an emphasis on painting. In between he also attended the Academy of Art in Stockholm where he was taught by Torben Grut, architect of the 1912 Olympic Stadium. During this period, Rohweder also travelled extensively in Europe, including England, Germany, Italy, Poland, France and others. Subsequently he opened his own design studio in København, while teaching classes at the Technical School and the School for Interior Design. During the 1930s and 1940 he designed functional villas, town and country houses focusing on practical design with a view to their locality and proportions. In the 1950s Rohweder designed condominium houses and hotels. He also made illustrations for magazines and books and painted in oils. He regularly participated in art exhibitions, mostly in Scandinavia. The Swimming hall was designed in 1931 for a competition in Berlin at a time when he was still a student.

name: Olaf Ørvig
description: Olaf Ørvig was the owner of the yacht Heira II. He started as a manager for the Poseidon insurance company and became head of the Bergen branch office. From 1914 he was the owner of a shipping company which he named after himself. He was active in several commercial shipping federations and on the board of the Bergen art museum. Together with Hans Stoermann-Næss Ørvig competed in car races on ice. Olaf’s brothers Erik and Thor were also members of the crew.
special_notes: Brother of Erik Ørvig Brother of Thor Ørvig

name: Jörg Stratmann
description: Sabre fencer Jörg Stratmann was a member of the West German sabre team at the 1984 Los Angeles. The team finished an unfortunate fourth and Scholz placed 22nd individually. Nationally, Stratmann won the individual sabre title in 1974, 1978-79, and 1984. His father Günter fenced at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. Jörg Stratmann later became a journalist, working with renowned newspapers like “Die Welt”, “Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung” and with the German Olympic Sports Federation.
special_notes: Son of Günter Stratmann

name: Enrique Granados
description: Enrique Granados Aumacellas grew up in an aquatics family as his father, Enrique Granados Gal, competed at the 1920 and 1924 Olympics in water polo. Granados Aumacellas competed for Spain at the 1952 Helsinki Olympics as a distance swimmer. He later became President of the Balearic Swimming Federation and was awarded the Silver Medal for Sports Merit, as well as the Honor Plate of the Spanish Swimming Federation. He continued to swim into his 80s, and in 2015 participated in a relay marathon in Menorca. In 2017 he competed in the VIIIth Cala Gran-Cala d’Or Crossing in Mallorca.
special_notes: Son of Enrique Granados Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–1–3 1951 Al-Iskanderiya SWI silver: 4×200 m freestyle relay, bronze: 400 m freestyle and 1500 m freestyle; 1955 Barcelona SWI bronze: 4×200 m freestyle relay)

name: Nikolaos Baltatzis-Mavrokordatos
description: Nikolaos Baltatzis-Mavrokordatos was a water polo player who competed at the 1920 and 1924 Olympic Games. Baltatzis-Mavrokordatos studied law in Athina and München and then went into journalism and politics. His journalism career started with the newspaper Kathimerini. In 1936 he was elected to parliament from the People’s Party, while in 1946-47 he served as Press Minister and was then the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs. Baltatzis-Mavrokordatos was a member of the Hellenic Nautical Club and the Athenian Club. He also served in sports administration, as President of the Greek Wrestling Federation, and as a member of the Hellenic Olympic Committee, serving as second vice-president from 1957-60.

name: Hermann Buhl
description: Hermann Buhl is well known for the “Sport Picture of the Year 1958”, taken when he fell head first into the water jump of the steeplechase, although he won that race! As an athlete, he was eliminated in the heats at the 1960 Rome Olympic Games with the mixed German team, and was German steeplechase champion in 1958-59 and 1961-62. Later he became one the best known sport physicians in the former GDR, who insisted that he had nothing to do with doping practices. After the reunification of Germany this was confirmed by the investigations of the Gauck Agency, who also confirmed that he never worked with or for the Stasi (State Security). He made his living as a medical doctor in East Germany and later the reunified Germany. In March 2014 Buhl went for a mountain hike and went missing from that day, with a search operation failing to find him. He was finally found at 1700 m elevation on 19 August 2014 in the Tyrolean area of Reith near Seefeld with his body severely decomposed. The precise cause of death could not be determined but he did not have a severe fall. Personal Best: 3000S – 8:34.0 (1960).

name: Giovanni Mezzani
description: A running target specialist, Giovanni Mezzani had the honor of representing Italy at four consecutive Olympic Games from 1972 to 1984. Born in Pistoia but living in nearby Agliana, Mezzani was a member of TSN Pistoia. He won about 50 international caps and was a 10-time Italian champion, as well as having held the Italian record in running target for many years. A military officer with the Army General Staff, Mezzani began shooting in 1969 and in the following year placed 26th overall and fourth with the team at the World Championships in Phoenix, Arizona. He then finished fourth individually at the 1971 European Championships at Suhl, and then in 1972 competed at his first Olympics. In the following years Mezzani confirmed himself as the best Italian specialist in running target, reaching the highlight of his international career at the 1978 Worlds in Seoul, where he won the individual and team titles, also setting an individual world record. After ending his competitive career at high levels, he then won the Italian Masters Championship six times and two Carabinieri champion titles. Married to Silvia Agostini, they had a son, Francesco, who became an officer in the Italian Navy.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (2–0–1 1975 München bronze: 50 m running target; 1978 Seoul gold: 50 m mixed running target and 50 m mixed running target team) Listed in Olympians Who Received the Italian Olympic Association (CONI) Gold Medal ()

name: Michal Palinek
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Beach Volleyball Championships (1–0–0 1996 Pescara gold)

name: Achim Hill
description: Sculler Achim Hill won two silver medals with the mixed German team in 1960 at Roma and 1964 at Tokyo, becoming the first East German rower to win Olympic medals. He then finished fifth for East Germany at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics. In 1957 he won his first East German title, the coxless pairs, while in 1959-60 and 1962-67 he won the single sculls titles. In 1959 and 1960 he also took the double sculls championships. At the 1966 Worlds he came in fourth and in 1967 he was European Champion just ahead of Soviet Vyacheslav Ivanov, at the time the world’s dominant sculler. Hill first studied airplane construction in West Berlin until the wall was raised and he then had to move to Dresden. He later married his teammate and non-Olympian Gisela Jäger. By profession he became an engineer for rail vehicles.

description: Elvis Forde finished sixth in the 400 metres at the 1987 Pan American Games. Personal Best: 400 – 45.32 (1984).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–0–2 1986 Santiago de los Caballeros ATH bronze: 400 m and 4×400 m relay)

name: Gwynne Evans
description: Gwynne Evans competed in no individual swimming events at the 1904 Olympics, He was a member of the Missouri AC team which played in the water polo tournament, finishing third. However, Evans was entered in the 50 yard freestyle but did not start.

name: Mercy Njoroge
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (0–0–1 2011 Daegu bronze: 3000 m steeplechase) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 2010 Delhi ATH silver: 3000 m steeplechase)

name: Helmut Gertel
description: West German boxer Helmut Gertel, brother of Stefan Gertel, had the misfortune at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics of meeting the eventual light-welterweight gold medalist, Jerry Page of the USA, in his first round bout. Gertel lost by a 5-0 decision. He never turned professional but engaged in around 200 amateur bouts, and perhaps surprisingly, he never won a national title.
special_notes: Brother of Stefan Gertel

name: Dorli Hofrichter
description: Track & field athlete Dorli Hofrichter was Austrian champion in shot put (1960 and 1963) and discus throw (1958-1963). She competed at the 1960 Rome Olympics where she was eliminated in the qualification of the discus throw. The same happened at the 1962 European Championships, but in 1958 she had finished 12th. Personal Best: DT – 50.52 (1960).

name: Stu Irving
description: Stu Irving was from Beverly, Massachusetts, and never played hockey collegiately. He played in Quebec with the Montreal Junior Canadiens in Junior A hockey, but was drafted into the US Army after the 1968 season and served in Vietnam in 1970. He was sent back to Minneapolis in 1972 to attend Olympic try-outs and made the 1972 USA Olympic team. He also played with the 1973 USA National team which played at the World Championships (B Division). Irving was drafted in 1972 by the New England Whalers of the World Hockey Association (WHA), but never played in the NHL or WHA. He spent his playng career after the Olympics in the minor professional leagues. He started out with the Jacksonville Barons of the American Hockey League, but played from 1972 until 1979 with the Saginaw Gears of the International Hockey League (IHL), and then finished his career in the IHL with the Grand Rapids Owls, Milwaukee Admirals, and Muskegon Mohawks, retiring after the 1982-83 season. Irving later became a hockey coach, coaching at Merrimack College. He stayed in shape by running and participated in the Boston Marathon in 1988 and 1991.

name: Renata Major-Kubik
description: Renata Major-Kubik had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 3rd 2007 K4 200 m (with Antonija Panda, Marta Tibor, and the non-Olympian Miljana Knežević).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint European Championships (0–0–1 2008 Milano bronze: K4 200 m) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (0–0–1 2007 Duisburg bronze: K4 200 m (competed as Renata Kubik))

name: Alex Antonitsch
description: Alex Antonitsch was an Austrian tennis player who played professionally from 1988 to 1996. During his career Antonitsch won one singles title and four doubles titles. He achieved his career-best world-ranking of 40 as a singles player in July 1990, and 54 as a doubles player in October 1989. Antonitsch was a member of the Austrian Davis Cup team from 1983 to 1996. During this time he played in 27 matches, the majority in doubles. In 1990 the Austrian team reached the semi-finals of the tournament. Antonitsch competed in both the singles and the doubles tournament at the 1988 Seoul Olympics. He lost his first-round match in the singles competition to Darren Cahill of Australia. In the doubles tournament he reached the second round. At the 1990 Wimbledon Championships Antonitsch was eliminated in the fourth round after losing to Ivan Lendl.

name: Birgit Rockmeier
description: German sprinter Birgit, twin sister of Gabi Rockmeier, was a member of the 4x400 metres relay squad at the 2000 Sydney Olympics, and the 4x100 metres squad at the Athens Games four years later. On both occasions, the German four was eliminated in the heats. In 2001, Rockmeier won gold at the World Championships with the 4 x100 metres (which was only adjudged in 2004 after the doping disqualification of the US team), and bronze at the World Indoors with the 4x400 relay. In 2002, she won the European Championships in the 4x400 and in 1998 the silver medal with the 4x100 squad. In total, Birgit Rockmeier won 16 German national titles in individual and relay events. By profession, the twins both became administrative clerks, and both also occasionally did some youth coaching. Personal Bests: 100 – 11.33 (2005); 400 – 51.45 (2000).
special_notes: Twin sister of Gabi Rockmeier Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (1–1–0 1998 Budapest silver: 4×100 m relay; 2002 München gold: 4×400 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (1–0–0 2001 Edmonton gold: 4×100 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Indoor Championships (0–0–1 2001 Lisboa bronze: 4×400 m relay)

name: Christian Hadinata
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (5–3–2 1974 Tehran BDM gold: mixed doubles, silver: doubles and team; 1978 Bangkok BDM gold: doubles and team, bronze: mixed doubles; 1982 New Delhi BDM gold: doubles and mixed doubles, silver: team; 1986 Seoul BDM bronze: team)

name: Jerzy, Count Potulicki-Skórzewski
description: Born in Austro-Hungary, Count Jerzy Potulicki-Skórzewski graduated from high school and was a student at several foreign universities. In addition to his native language, Count Potulicki-Skórzewski was fluent in German, French, English, Hungarian, and Spanish. During World War I, he was a second lieutenant in the German army and was awarded the Cross of Valour. During this time, he contracted tuberculosis. Count Potulicki-Skórzewski was transferred to the reserve as a captain in the 21st Cavalry Regiment Vistula. In 1919, he joined the newly formed Polish Army as a captain with the 16th Cavalry Regiment of Wielkopolska. While undergoing tuberculosis treatment in Switzerland, he served as a military attache at the Polish embassy in Bern. He later joined the service of the Foreign Department of the Presidential Office and became liaison officer from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to the II. Division of the Supreme Command. As a relative of Józef Broel-Plater Count Potulicki-Skórzewski became a member of the Polish bobsled crew at the 1928 Olympic Winter Games.
special_notes: Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Count)

name: Gyula Bóbis
description: Gyula Bóbis started his sports career as a football player of Kecskeméti TE, then switched to wrestling due to the influence of his older brother. Coming to Budapest in 1932 he first competed in the colors of BVSC. In 1939 he moved to MAC, and in 1945 back to BVSC. He started as a flyweight and achieved his greatest successes as a light-heavyweight and heavyweight. He competed both in freestyle and Greco-Roman. Between 1934 and 1950 he won 23 individual and five team champion titles. Between 1936 and 1950 he wrestled for the Hungarian national team thirty-one times. In 1936, he took part in the Berlin Olympics, where he was eliminated after two defeats and finished unplaced in heavyweight in Greco-Roman. He achieved his greatest success at the 1948 London Olympics, where he won the gold medal out of nine competitors in freestyle heavyweight. He took third place twice at the European Championships (in 1937 in München freestyle, heavyweight and in 1939 in Oslo in Greco-Roman style, heavyweight). In 1950, at the world championship in Stockholm in the Greco-Roman, Bóbis won the silver medal in the heavyweight. After a serious eye injury, however, he retired in 1951. After his retirement, he worked as a MÁV (Hungarian Railway) official. In 1971 he received the Order of Merit of the International Wrestling Federation (FILA). Bóbis read a lot and studied French and Greek to write the ancient history of wrestling. He loved chess and music, played the piano, and sang opera arias. A square and a training hall in Kecskemét were named after him. Of his five children, Ildikó achieved the greatest sporting success, becoming the world champion and an Olympic silver medalist in fencing.
special_notes: Father of Ildikó Farkasinszky-Bóbis

name: Vladimir Nevzorov
description: Vladimir Nevzorov was one of the best lightweight and half-middleweight judokas in the world during the mid-1970s. Nevzorov was 1976 Olympic half-middleweight champion and in 1975 became the first Soviet judoka to win a World title (in half-middleweight). He also won two individual European titles (1975 in half-middleweight and 1977 in lightweight), three team European titles (1973, 1975, 1977) and won the European sambo (a Soviet wrestling style similar to judo) lightweight title in 1972. Domestically, Nevzorov won Soviet judo half-middleweight titles in 1975-76 and a lightweight title in 1979. He was also Soviet sambo lightweight champion in 1971 and 1972. After finishing his sporting career, Nevzorov worked as a judo and sambo coach. From 1980-89 he was the coach of the Soviet national team and from 1989-91 he was a judo coach in France. He was head coach of the Russian national judo team from 1999-2001 and the head coach of the 2000 Russian Olympic judo team. Nevzorov later became vice-president of the Russian Judo federation.

name: Ernie Riedel
description: Ernie Riedel is probably the greatest kayaker the United States has yet produced. But canoeing did not become an Olympic sport until 1936 and when the war intervened in 1940 and 1944, Riedel missed what might have been his best Olympic years. Still, his bronze medal is the only medal won by an American in kayak events. Riedel’s canoeing victories are too numerous to fully enumerate. Briefly he won 33 national championships, mostly in kayak, although he occasionally raced in the Canadian events. In a yearly international race held against Canada, Riedel won 18 times between 1923 and 1947. Although by then he was 47 years old, he also raced in the 1948 Olympics.

name: Nina Petrova

name: Sue Rembao
description: Sue Rembao was a high jumper who competed at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. She jumped in college at Cal Poly SLO, winning the 1983 D-2 NCAA Championship, after placing second in 1981-82. She was US Olympic Festival Champion in 1991 and competed at the World Championships in 1991 and 1993. At the USA Championships, she was runner-up in 1991 and finished third in 1992-93. She was ranked in the US top 10 for eight years, with high rankings of #2 in 1991-92. She later went into coaching, serving stints at her alma mater, the University of Arizona, and the University of Texas. Rembao is a member of the Cal Poly SLO Hall of Fame. Personal Best: HJ – 1.96 (1991).

name: Gheorghe Gușet
description: Gheorghe Guşet was a three-time Olympian in the shot put, competing in 1992, 2000, and 2004. He was Romanian Champion in the shot put in 1990, 1992-94, and 1998-2006, winning 13 times in all. He competed six times at the World Championships, four times at the Europeans, six times at the World Indoors, and five times at the European Indoors. He was Balkan Games champion with the shot in 1990, 1992, 1999-2002, and 2004-05, also winning that title indoors in 1994, 1999-2002, and 2004-06. His only other international title came in winning the 1994 Jeux de la Francophone. His best major international placing came in finishing fourth at the World Indoors in 2000 and 2006. Guşet competed into his late 30s, only retiring from competition when he began to suffer the effects of chronic kidney failure. He underwent a kidney transplant in 2008, but eventually died from complications of kidney disease at 49-years-old. Personal Best: SP – 21.04i (2006).

name: Charles Lakes
description: Charles Lakes was the first African-American to compete for the USA in gymnastics at the Olympics, although Ron Galimore made the 1980 US Olympic team that did not compete. Lakes competed for the US at the 1985 and 1987 World Championships. In college he competed for the University of Illinois, winning an NCAA title on high bar in 1984. High bar was considered his best event. He also won a US title on floor exercise in 1988. Lakes later went into Scientology auditing with his father, and together they also started Humanonics Insurance Services. Charles Lakes was inducted into the USA Gymnastics Hall of Fame in 2003.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1987 Indianapolis GYM gold: team)

name: Lynne Jewell
description: Lynne Jewell grew up sailing in California, but often sailed on the East Coast when she visited her grandparents in Plymouth, Massachusetts, where she often spent summers. She attended Boston University, graduating in 1981, and later lived in Rhode Island with her sailing partner and future husband, Bill Shore, although they would eventually divorce. Jewell won gold at the 1988 Seoul Olympics in the 470 class, sailing alongside Allison Jolly. She won International Yacht Racing Union championships in 1980 and 1984, and was named Rolex Yachtswomen of the year in 1980 and 1988. She was New York Yacht Club’s Yachtswoman of the Year in 1980 and the US Olympic Committee yachting athlete-of-the-year in 1984. Jewell later earned a masters’ degree in education from Northeastern University. Although she trained for a career in the pharmaceutical industry, she changed course and then graduated from the Rhode Island School of Design’s interior design program, eventually working in interior design in sales and non-profit management. She is a member of the National Kitchen & Bath Association and the American Society of Interior Designers.

name: Maria Sykora
description: Maria Sykora won 23 Austrian titles in 400 metres (1967-1971), 800 metres (1968, 1969, 1971, and 1972), cross country (1968-1971), 4×100 relay (1964 and 1970-1973), 4×400 relay (1971 and 1973), 100 metres hurdles (1970), and pentathlon ([100H-SP-HJ-LJ-200], 1970 and 1971). Personal Bests: 400 – 52.7 (1972); 800 – 2:01.5 (1972).

name: Rainer Schönborn
description: West German ice dancer Rainer Schönborn skated with Petra Born from 1981-85 and competed regularly both at the Europeans and the Worlds. In 1985 they had their best season, placing fifth at the Worlds and winning a European bronze medal. At the 1984 Sarajevo Winter Olympics they finished ninth. In 1981 and 1982 the couple was runner-up at the West German nationals and from 1983-85 they won three national titles in a row. Schönborn earned a degree in business administration and worked as a key account manager in a marketing and sales company. He and his wife raised three children.

name: Stanley Wudyka
description: Stanley Wudyka placed third in the AAU 10K in 1936, and repeated that finish at the Olympic Trials to make the team. Wudyka also finished fourth in the 5K at the 1933 AAU Meet. He competed for Temple, the Mid-Atlantic Association, and the Meadowbrook Club of Philadelphia. Wudyka graduated from Temple in 1935 and later earned a masters’ degree in education from the University of Pennsylvania. Personal Best: 10000 – 32:05e (1936).

name: Annelore Zückert
description: Annelore Zückert was an Austrian alpine skier who participated in the 1948 St. Moritz Winter Olympics. She finished 16th in the downhill event and was disqualified in the slalom event. She won four national titles after World War II: alpine combined in 1947 and the combined, downhill, and slalom in 1950. In total, Zückert won 13 international FIS races. After her active career Zückert became a physiotherapist. She then married Rudolf Zrost, a bakery entrepreneur and raised two children.

name: Fritz Roderfeld
description: At the 1964 Tokyo Olympics Fritz Roderfeld reached the second round of the 200. His biggest moment came at the 1966 European Championships when he earned a silver medal with the 4x400 relay and finished sixth in the 200. One year later, at the European Cup, Roderfeld was runner-up with the relay and in the 400. He earned his only West German title in 1967 in the 400. Roderfeld later became a sprint coach at the well-known German soccer club FC Schalke 04 from 1970-80. Personal Best: 200 – 20.8 (1966).

name: John Ngugi
description: John Ngugi’s is best remembered for his triumphs at the International Cross-Country Championships, where he won a record four consecutive titles between 1986 and 1989 and then won his fifth title in 1992. Ngugi established himself on the track in the 5,000 metres at the 1987 World Championships. After winning his heat, Ngugi took the lead in the final during the second kilometre but was outsprinted in the finish, eventually finishing 12th. In 1987 Ngugi won the 5,000 m at the All-African Games. At the Seoul Olympic Games, Ngugi took the lead after 1,000 metres and opened a 50 metre lead, finally holding on to win by 30 metres. At the 1990 Commonwealth Games, Ngugi tried the same tactic, but tripped and fell at the end of the second lap and lost contact with the field. He actually caught back, and then opened a 40 metre gap by the bell, but was eventually caught by Australian Andrew Lloyd, who won by 0.08 seconds in a stunning finishing burst. Ngugi never again competed at a major international. In 1993 he refused to take an out-of-competition drug test and received a four-year suspension which effectively ended his competitive career. Personal Best: 5000 – 13:11.14 (1990).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 1990 Auckland ATH silver: 5000 m)

name: Karl-Heinz Fuhrmann
description: Karl-Heinz Fuhrmann was an eventing rider from Potsdam, East Germany. He finished third with the mixed German team at the 1964 Tokyo Olympic Games, but did not receive a medal as his score did not count towards the team score. Four years later in Mexico City, then representing East Germany he came in seventh with the team. In both games he finished 25th in the individual event. Fuhrmann was East German champion in 1961-62 and 1969.

name: Lucien Large
special_notes: Brother of Jules Large

name: William Coles
description: Before joining the Metropolitan Police, William Coles was educated at the Central School in Tysoe, Warwickshire. Having previously played rugby for Banbury and Oxfordshire, he also played for the “Met” XV and even had an international trial during his spell in the force. He was commissioned into the RAF in 1938 and, after training, was posted to bomber command in Egypt and then took part in the invasion of Sicily. He was involved in some of the major campaigns of World War II, and later commanded a joint British-American squadron that dropped supplies to troops in hazardous destinations, and in dangerous conditions. For his exploits, Coles received many decorations, including, in 1952, a CBE to go with his DFC and Bar, DSO, AFC and the American DFC. After the War, he served at the AIr Ministry, Central Flying School, and H.Q. Flying Training Command. In 1963, Air Vice-Marshal Coles was appointed the Director-General of personal services at the Air Ministry, and in 1966 was promoted to Air Marshal. After World War II, Coles continued his sporting exploits. A fine squash player, he resumed his rugby career with Blackheath, and raced many times with the RAF bobsleigh team at St. Moritz and in 1947 was in the 4-man team that won the St. Moritz Cup. At the Olympic Games the following year, Coles, and fellow RAF man Pennington Collings, competed in the 2-man bob, finishing a creditable fifth. He was also part of the British 4-man team that finished seventh. Coles was vice-captain of the two British bob teams at the Games, while Collings was captain of both.

name: Jorge Lugo
description: Jorge Lugo was a Venezuelan judoka. Lugo was the first person to represent Venezuela in judo at the Olympics when he competed in the middleweight category at the 1964 Tokyo Games. Drawn in Pool H he lost both his bouts, to Fernando Costa Matos and eventual gold medal winner Isao Okano, and therefore did not progress any further. In the same year as the Olympics he won bronze at the United States National Championships in New York City. In 1965 Lugo competed at the World Judo Championships and the following year he won a silver medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games.

name: Ede Tóth
description: As a member of the Budapest Lawn Tennis Club, Ede Tóth finished runner-up in the Hungarian Tennis Championship at the age of 18. He went on to win two singles titles, in 1904 and 1908, and in the latter year reached the second round at the London Olympics. In the doubles, he partnered Jenő Zsigmondy, but they were defeated in their opening match by the eventual silver medallists, Josiah Ritchie and James Parke of Great Britain. After finishing his playing career, Tóth served briefly as national coach and was a member of the Bureau of the Hungarian National Lawn Tennis Federation, and later, an Honorary Member.

name: Martin Lang
description: Martin Lang was a German whitewater canoeist who specialised in the Canadian singles. He finished a disappointing sixth at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics and seventh in 1996 Atlanta four years later. In 1992, Lang won the overall World Cup, and in 1991 and 1993 he won World Championships C1 gold medals, and added a team gold in 1995, and silver in 1999. At theEuropeans, he won one medal of each colour; team gold in 1996, team silver in 1998, and individual bronze in 1996. Lang won national titles in 1988, 1990, 1994-96, and 1999. By profession, he became a temporary soldier, freelance fitness coach and, finally, an office clerk at the Regional Sports Federation of Bavaria. He also acted as an assistant coach of the German Canoe Slalom Canadian team for two years.

name: Göpf Kottmann
description: Göpf Kottmann started rowing at age 13, with the Belvoir Ruderclub in Zürich. He became one of Switzerland’s most versatile rowers, winning national titles in eight different events. In 1954 and 1955, he won the European title in the coxed pairs with Rolf Streuli and coxswain Walter Ludin. The boat was unable to compete at the Melbourne Olympics, as Switzerland was one of the few countries boycotting the Games due to the Hungarian Revolt. They won two more medals at the Europeans but Streuli and Kottmann also joined the national quadruple sculls boat, winning a European bronze in 1957. With his team mates retiring from rowing, Kottmann switched to the single sculls. In 1963, he won the Henley regatta, and reached the World Championships final, where he placed sixth after leading at the halfway point. At the Tokyo Olympics, he was more successful, taking home a bronze medal. Besides rowing, Kottmann was also an active bobsledder. As a crew-member of Max Angst, he won a World Championship bronze in 1961, as well as three Swiss titles in the four-man sled. Just a month after winning his Olympic medal, Göpf Kottmann drowned in Rhine while taking part in a military exercise as a frogman.

name: Bogdan Musiol
description: Bogdan Musiol was the winner of an Olympic gold medal with the GDR four-man bobsled team in 1980, when he also won a bronze medal in the two-man. He went on to win silver medals in 1984 and 1988, at both the two- and four-man, and, in 1992, won a silver medal in the two-man. In 1989, Musiol won the world two-man title as the brakeman for Wolfgang Hoppe, with whom he won an Olympic silver in 1988. At the World Championships Musiol earned three more golds, and two silver and two bronze medals between 1978 and 1991. At the European Championships he added two more golds, and four silver and bronze medals. Musiol was born in Poland and emigrated with his family to East Germany during the 1960s. In the former GDR he started his sports career as a shot putter but turned to bobsleigh very soon. In 1992, he was awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, Germany’s highest sports award. During his sports career Musiol was employed by the National People’s Army (Nationale Volksarmee). In 2000, he became groundsman of the German Bobsleigh, Luge and Skeleton Federation. His son Julian was a nationally successful ski jumper.

name: Joseph Jessop
description: Joseph Jessop joined the San Diego Yacht Club (SDYC) in 1917 and became the Commodore of the club in 1929, the youngest Commodore in SDYC history. Jessop was instrumental in starting the San Diego Bay Star fleet in 1925. He also was a supporter of junior sailing in the United States. Jessop won several Pacific Coast Championships and was second in the 1928 World Championships. He founded a family jewelry company and was active in civic affairs in San Diego.

name: Kerstin Emich
description: German extra-lightweight judoka Kerstin Emich lost her second-round bout against the Italian Giovanna Tortora at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics and was eliminated in the pool stage. She also lost to Tortora in the bronze medal matches at the 1990 and 1991 European Championships. Nationally, Emich won six titles in 1983, 1986-87, 1990-92. With her home club JC Rüsselsheim she also won the team titles in 1983 and 1986-87. Emich later became a graduated pharmacist and worked at the institute for clinical pharmacology at the Goethe University of Frankfurt.

name: Ernst Oberaigner
description: Ernst Oberaigner took up skiing during World War II and joined the national team in 1951. One year later, he won all of the disciplines at the Austrian junior national championships and was selected as a reserve with the delegation to the 1952 Oslo Olympics, but did not compete. His greatest international success came at the 1954 World Championships, when he won bronze in the downhill behind his compatriots Christian Pravda and Martin Strolz. He was unable to qualify for the Olympics in 1956, although he did win the senior national championship in the slalom that year, before breaking his leg twice. He did not rebound until the new decade, when he won the national combined title in 1960, and competed at that year’s Squaw Valley Olympics. There, in the slalom, he was disqualified in the second run. Oberaigner retired after these Games and turned to coaching, heading the national team from 1962 through 1964. He also served as a course setter for run #1 of the slalom at the 1964 Innsbruck Olympics. He then retired from coaching and worked at a ski company, before starting his own shop in Saalfelden, where he was also an official of the local ski club.

name: Dick Ault
description: The highlight of Dick Ault’s intermediate hurdling career came on 31 August 1949 at the famed Bislett Stadium in Oslo, when he set a 440 yard hurdle world record of 52.2 – although it was far inferior to the metric record. He ran for the University of Missouri and had a second place finish in the intermediates at the 1949 AAU. Ault became a professor of physical education at Westminister College and also coached track, cross-country, swimming, and golf at that school. He was elected a member of the Missouri Sports Hall of Fame. Personal Best: 440y – 48.4 (1949); 110H – 15.2 (1949); 400H – 51.4 (1949).

name: Juan Manuel García
description: Juan Manuel García was a member of the bronze medal winning team at the 1971 Pan American Games as well as of the gold medal winning team at the 1975 Pan American Games.
special_notes: Brother of Francisco García Brother of Víctor García Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–1 1971 Cali WAP bronze; 1975 Ciudad de México WAP gold) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–3–0 1970 Panamá WAP silver; 1974 Santo Domingo WAP silver; 1978 Medellín WAP silver)

name: Sheila Conover
description: Sheila Conover competed at three Olympics (1984-92) with a best finish of fourth in the K4 at the 1984 Los Angeles Games. She retired after the 1988 Olympics, while finishing her degree at UC Berkeley but came back in 1991 and made the 1992 Olympic team, despite training for only one year. While at Cal she competed on the crew team, while majoring in environmental geography. She also served as an assistant volleyball coach at St. Mary’s College in Moraga, California from 1989-90. Conover won two gold medals at the 1987 Pan American Games, in K2 and K4. Conover’s sister, Jenifer Conover Evans, was a high-level ocean sailor who sailed the Pacific and Indian Oceans and the Mediterranean Sea. Sheila later worked in sales with Farolline Yacht Sales and as a teacher in the Newport Mesa Unified School District.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (2–0–0 1987 Indianapolis CAN gold: K2 500 m and K4 500 m)

name: Johan Støa
description: Johan Støa participated both in the Winter and Summer Games in 1928. He was Norwegian Champion in athletics twice, winning the 10,000 metres on the track in 1924 and cross-country running in 1925. In skiing he was national champion in the 30 km cross-country in 1927. He was a man of endurance challenges. In 1935 he set a cycling record, covering the distance from Trondheim to Oslo in 21-56:50. He also twice set a walking record for the same distance – his best was 4 days 7 hours and 47 minutes in 1936 – and was also an excellent marathon swimmer. Støa ran a sport store in Drammen and was awarded the Egebergs Ærespris in 1926. Personal Best: Mar – 2-54:15 (1928).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Were Awarded Egebergs Ærespris (1926 - cross country skiing and athletics)

name: Salvatore Todisco
description: Salvatore Todisco was an Italian light-flyweight boxer who won a bronze medal at the 1983 Casablanca Mediterranean Games and repeated that finish at the 1987 Mediterranean Games. At the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, Todisco qualified for the final but was unable to match up there against American Paul Gonzales, Jr., due to a broken hand. He retired after the 1987 season and never turned professional. While later assisting Franco Falcinelli, the technical coach of the Italian amateur boxing team, Todisco lost his life in a car accident at the age of 29, when he was returning from Napoli.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–0–2 1983 Casablanca BOX bronze: light-flyweight -48 kg; 1987 Latakia BOX bronze: light-flyweight -48 kg) Listed in Olympians Who Died in Motor Vehicle Accidents (Boat/Car/Motorcycle/Train) (Died in a car accident.)

name: James Steen
description: James Steen was a member of the New York Athletic Club, and played on their championship water polo teams. He served with the 22nd Regiment of the New York National Guard during the Spanish-American War. Steen worked as an insurance broker.

name: Offutt Pinion
description: Offutt Pinion was a navy shooter in 1956 and contended with some horrible conditions to win the bronze medal in free pistol. The day of the event was very cold, with winds gusting up to 30 miles per hour. However, Pinion used some great wind doping to overcome one bad string of 88 and win the bronze medal. This was in his first international competition, although he had been All-Navy champion in 1956 and northwest regional champion in 1951 and 1952.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (0–2–0 1954 Caracas silver: 50 m free pistol team; 1958 Moskva silver: 50 m free pistol team)

name: Rudi Fink
description: East German featherweight boxer Rudi Fink became Olympic Champion at the 1980 Moskva Olympics. In the semi-finals he beat Russian Viktor Rybakov by a 4-1 decision, which was the same result as the final against Adolfo Horta from Cuba. Fink won national titles in 1977 and 1979-80 as a featherweight. In 1993, Fink started a coaching career, but between 1994 and 2003 he had worked as an educator at Cottbus, after having been jobless for a time, although he had studied automobile repair and sports. In 2003 he joined the boxing camp of former world-class boxer and his coach at the 1980 Olympics Manfred Wolke, although Wolke released him in 2008.

name: Antje Buschschulte
description: Antje Buschschulte started to swim at the early age of seven, and in 1993 had her first international competition. She was a sprint specialist in both freestyle and backstroke and for 14 years was one of the most successful competitive German female swimmers after German reunification. In total she won 24 national titles and over 50 international medals at World and European Championships, and at the Olympics, including five bronzes at the Olympics. These included a 1996 Olympic Games bronze medal in the 4×100 free relay, 2000 Olympic bronze medal in the 4×200 free relay, and 2004 Olympic bronzes in the 200 back, 4×200 free relay and medley relay. At the Worlds she won gold in the 2001 4×100 free relay and 2003 100 back, adding silvers in 2003 in the 50 backstroke and 4×100 free relay and a bronze in the 100 backstroke, and at the 2005 World Championships she won silver in the 100 back and 4×100 free relay, and bronzes in the 50 back and medley relay. At the European Championships, where she competed from 1997-2006, she won six gold, three silver, and four bronze medals. In November 2008 Buschschulte retired and earned her doctoral degree in neurobiology at the Otto-von-Guericke Universität in Magdeburg. She then married her partner, German swimmer Helge Meeuw. Personal Bests: 100 freestyle – 54.39 (2000); 200 freestyle – 2:00.25 (2000); 100 backstroke – 1:00.33 (2003); 200 backstroke – 2:09.88 (2004).

name: Rudolf Eggenberg
description: Personal Best: HJ – 1.915 (1933).

name: Andrea Wieland
description: Andrea Wieland was a goalkeeper who played for the USA women’s hockey team at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. Weiland attended the University of Iowa, where she earned a baccalaureate degree, an MBA, and a PhD in psychology. Wieland won silver at the 1995 Pan American Games and also won bronze medals at the 1994 World Cup and the 1995 Champions Trophy. Wieland later went into training and counseling athletes. She has worked at Winning Systems, Inc., ICPH, E1Fit, and as a counselor and mental performance specialist at the IMG Academy.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1995 Mar del Plata HOK silver)

name: John Trevorrow
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1970 Edinburgh CYC bronze: road race)

name: Jaime Oncins
description: Jaime Oncins was a Brazilian tennis player who played professionally from 1988 to 2001. Oncins achieved a career-best singles ranking of #34 in the world in May 1993, and a doubles ranking of #22 in the world in July 2000. He played on Brazil’s Davis Cup team from 1991 to 2001. On the ATP Challenger and ITF Futures circuit Oncins won eight singles titles and 11 doubles titles during his career. Stepping up to the ATP Tour he won five doubles titles between 1991 and 1999. He also won two singles titles, both in 1992, with victories against Renzo Furlan and Luis Herrera. At Grand Slams Oncins had his best results at the French Open. In 1992 he reached the fourth round in the singles, and in 2000 he was a semi-finalist in the doubles. At the 2001 edition he and Paola Suárez of Argentina reached the finals in the mixed doubles but lost to the Spanish duo of Tomás Carbonell and Vivi Ruano. Oncins competed in the singles and doubles at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics where he got to the quarter-finals in the former before losing to Andrey Cherkasov. Eight years later he returned to the Olympics, playing in the doubles with Guga Kuerten.

special_notes: Sister of Vicky Grau

name: Cosimo Campioto
description: Rino Campioto rowed for the Marina Militare in Roma and competed at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics in the coxed eights, where his crew was eliminated at the semi-final stage. Back in Italy, he was well-known in his home city of Brindisi for his internationally popular pizza establishment called “Boomerang“, so called as a reminder of his Olympic experience. In 1990, Rino, along with wife Monika (who he met during the Olympics) and four daughters, moved from Italy to live in Sydney. However, he always maintained close links with Brindisi, coming back occasionally for summer holidays, or for the annual city festival. Rino, a father-in-law, grandfather and great-grandfather, passed away peacefully in Sydney at almost 85-years-of-age.

name: Sándor Eckschmiedt
description: Sándor Eckschmiedt started to boxing as a child at KISTEXT, then he played football for a while at Lőrinci Fonó, and finally ended up in athletics when he was a third-grade high school student. In 1959 he started studying at the College of Physical Education and transferred his affiliation. He was called up to the national team for the first time in 1962 at the European Championships in Belgrade, where he reached the final and finished eleventh. From there he became a stable member of the Hungarian national team. Although he did not stand on the podium in a world competition during his career, he represented Hungary in three more continental competitions (1966, 1969, 1971) and three Olympics (1964, 1968, 1972), and reached the finals in all major international competitions. He already participated in the summer games as an athlete of Újpesti Dózsa, where he did athletics from 1964 until the end of his career in 1976. He won the Hungarian championship in the hammer throw in 1972 and five times as team champion with Dózsa. He appeared in the Hungarian national team 29 times, achieving his personal best result of 71.96 meters in 1972. After his retirement, he took on a role not only as a coach, but also in the management of the sport. At Újpest he first worked as a coach and then as a sports psychologist, and in 1980 he became a university lecturer at the TF (College of Physical Education) Athletics Department, first as an assistant professor. From 1985 he researched and taught as a university associate professor. Between 1976 and 1984 he was a member of the hammer throw section of the Hungarian Athletic Association and, at the same time, he was a member of the coaching committee of the Hungarian Athletic Association between 1978 and 1980. Personal Best: HT – 71.96 (1972).

name: Albin Felc
description: His daughter, Sabina, played for the Slovenia national basketball team.

name: Anton Crișan
description: Anton Crişan played for Steaua Bucaresti from 1960-72, leading them to the national title as goaltender every year. He also won 6 Romanian Cups during his career as a player. Crişan led Romania to a third-place finish at the 1963 World Championships B Division, and he competed five times at the European Championships. He later became coach of Steaua Bucaresti, the Army team, from 1982-97, leading them to 14 national titles and 13 Romania Cups. He was also national team coach from 1993-95.

description: Eduard Vanaaseme had the following podium finishes at major championships: 2nd in the 1922 World Championships Lightweight class. He set one lightweight press world record in 1922.

name: Carlos de Candamo
description: Carlos de Candamo was born in London, the son of a Peruvian diplomat and nephew of the future President of Peru, Manuel Candamo Iriarte. He moved to Paris when his father was appointed ambassador to France and was to show his talents in a variety of sports. In 1891 he played in the very first match at the tennis tournament that later became the French Open, and the following year captained Racing Club de France to victory in the inaugural French national rugby championship. The game was refereed by none other than Baron de Coubertin. De Candamo also played, alongside his two brothers, in the Racing Club team that lost the championship final in 1893. The 1900 Olympics saw him take part in the fencing competition, he came through two rounds of the foil but was eliminated in the first round of the épée, and he also took part in the tennis competition, albeit in the non-Olympic handicap events. He was invited to join the IOC in 1909 and remained a member until his resignation in 1922. De Candamo followed his father into the world of diplomacy and in his position as “Envoy extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of Peru at Paris” signed the Treaty of Versailles on behalf of his nation.
special_notes: Brother of Gonzalo de Candamo

name: Carl Lovsted
description: Carl Lovsted made the 1952 Olympic team as a member of the University of Washington four. He had attended Franklin High School in the Seattle area, and would later graduate from Washington with a degree in business. While rowing for the Huskies, he was on the 1950 eight that won the IRA Regatta, and the 1951 crew that finished second to Cal at the same race. He settled in the Seattle area, starting a career in insurance with his own firm, working in that field for over 40 years. He later sold the firm to his son, which later merged with another to become the Lovsted-Worthington Insurance Brokerage.

name: Noël Desaubliaux
description: Noël Desaubliaux made his début at the Sailing World Championship in 1956, when he and Georges Pisani finished 13th among 18 teams in the Star class. In 1960 the duo won the gold medal in that division at the European Championships and were selected to represent France at that year’s Olympics. There they placed 11th overall, with a best finish of seventh in the third race. They went on to rank 31st among 73 pairs in the Star class at the 1962 World Championships. Between 1967 and 1985, Desaubliaux served as president of the Club Nautique de Cancale in Ille-et-Vilaine, where he lived much of his life.

name: Almiro Bergamo
description: Almiro Bergamo won a silver medal at the 1936 Berlin Olympics in coxed pairs. He later won European titles in Berlin in 1935 and Milano in 1938. He also won a silver medal at the 1937 Europeans in Amsterdam.

name: Dagobert Sekullic
description: Italian-born Austrian dressage rider Dagobert Sekullic was selected for the 1924 Paris Olympics. He finished 22nd in the individual event. He later worked as a horse breaker at the exclusive “Wiener Reitinstitut”.

name: Thomas Homewood
description: Thomas Homewood was a member of the K Division of the Metropolitan Police tug-of-war team that won the bronze medal outright after their scheduled opponents Sweden scratched. Homewood lost his life in the closing stages of World War II when his Stratford home was hit during a V2 rocket attack on London. The accident also claimed the life of his wife Matilda, son Victor (aged 25), and daughters Beatrice (23) and Ellen (15).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Were Killed or Missing in Action or Died as a Result of War (†1 February 1945. Killed in a V2 rocket attack on London.)

description: Filemón Camacho finished sixth in the 1955 Pan American Games 1500 metres. Personal Bests: 800 – unknown; 1500 – unknown.

name: Volker Ohl
description: Pole vaulter Volker Ohl came in sixth at the 1972 München Olympics, the same as he would at the 1974 European Indoors. In 1970 and 1973 he was West German champion, also winning indoors in 1974. In his youth Ohl was an artistic cycler. He later turned to inline skating and in 2002 was Hessian champion in the marathon distance in the M50 senior class. His son Thorsten was also a pole vaulter. Personal Best: PV – 5.31 (1972).

name: João Pedro Monteiro
special_notes: Husband of Daniela Dodean-Monteiro Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Games (0–0–1 2019 Minsk TTN bronze: team)

name: Sylvain Guillaume
description: Sylvain Guillaume competed in Nordic combined, winning two Olympic medals, an individual silver in 1992 behind his teammate Fabrice Guy, and a bronze in the 1998 team event at Nagano. Guillaume competed in World Cup events from 1987-2001, with five podium appearances, including one victory, at Liberec in January 1996. He had three top 10s in the seasonal World Cup standings, sixth in 1996 and 1998 and seventh in 1992. A five-time French champion (1988, 1994, 1996, 1999, 2001), Guillaume later worked in a civil job with the Douanes administrative department.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Nordic Ski Championships (0–0–1 1995 Thunder Bay NCB bronze: individual)

name: Andrzej Grabarczyk
description: Andrzej Grabarczyk was a long and triple jumper, who was a seven-time Polish Champion. He won the triple jump outdoors in 1988, 1990, and 1991, and indoors in 1989-91, adding an indoor long jump title in 1991. In addition to his two Olympic appearances, Grabarczyk competed at the 1991 World Championships, placing 12th in triple jump. He also competed in the World Indoor Championships (1989, 1991), twice and the European Indoor Championships in 1989 an 1990. Grabarczyk competed in six international matches for Poland. Personal Best: TJ – 17.00 (1991).

name: Peter Brotherton
description: Although he took part in the tandem event in Melbourne, Brotherton’s greatest international successes came as a pursuiter. He won World Championship silver medals in the amateur individual pursuit in both 1954 and 1955 and a silver in the individual pursuit at the 1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games. He also finished fourth in the 1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games track time trail and competed in the Sprint 1000 metres. In the British Empire and Commonwealth Games he competed for England. Shortly after the Olympics, Brotherton settled in Australia where he teamed up with Sid Patterson to win the 1958 Six Days of Sydney race.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 1954 Vancouver CYC silver: 4000 m individual pursuit (competed for England))

name: Peter Purcell-Gilpin
special_notes: Husband of Micheen Thornycroft

name: Olivier Allamand
description: Born in a small town just outside Grenoble, Olivier Allamand was a member of the very successful French moguls skiing team at the 1992 Olympics. With freestyle skiing making its début at these Olympics, the host nation was close to a medal sweep. Favourite Edgar Grospiron was the clear winner, but the difference between 2nd and 4th was just 0.12 points. Allamand won the silver medal, mostly by merit of his superior turns technique. Active on the World Cup circuit since 1986, Allamand had his best season in 1990, when he placed second in both the overall World Cup and the moguls World Cup. He won a total of five World Cup events, and placed fifth at both the 1989 and 1991 World Championships. Having long suffered from an anterior cruciate ligament injury, he retired after the Lillehammer Games. He later opened a sporting goods store in La Plagne, one of the Olympic towns of 1992.

name: Charles Daggs
description: Charles Daggs ran for Claremont College in Pomona, and after graduation, for the Los Angeles AC. He finished fourth at the 1920 US Olympic Trials to make the team for Antwerpen. Daggs later became a high school physics and chemistry teacher in California, teaching at Granite Hills, El Cajon, and Grossmont High schools. He taught for 33 years before retiring. Personal Best: 400H – 54.3 (1920).

name: Bernard van Vlijmen
description: Bernard van Vlijmen was born in Den Haag, and lived in Nijmegen until 1910. He studied at the Amsterdam Royal Academy and was mostly active in advertising art and book illustrations in the 1920s and 1930s. In Amsterdam van Vlijmen developed into a much sought-after painter of cityscapes and portraits of actors, actresses and politicians. In 1952, he painted a life-size portrait of the future Queen Elizabeth II, which is now in Buckingham Palace. He travelled frequently to Italy, Spain, Switzerland and South America. From 1963 he lived permanently in Bardolino, Italy. The style of his drawings and paintings was naturalistic. The motif of a finish in a bicycle race as in his Finish of Cycling Road Race is included in a calendar illustrated by van Vlijmen for the 1928 Olympic Games commissioned by the Holland-America Line.

name: Nicola Birkner
description: At the 2000 Sydney Olympics, German sailor Nicola Birkner partnered Wibke Bülle in the two-person keelboat (470 class) but only finished fifth, despite being one of the favourites. They lost the silver medal after finishing 15th in the last race. At World Championships they won a silver medal in 1997 and two bronzes in 1996 and 1998. Birkner later sailed mostly in the 505 class.

name: George Breed
description: George Breed won the Intercollegiate Fencing Association (IFA) title in 1899 and led Harvard to the team title that year. He later won the Amateur Fencers League of America (AFLA) titles in foil and épée in 1911. At the 1908 AFLA Championships he won bronze medals in foil, épée, and 3-weapon, while in 1909 he won silver medals in foil and 3-weapon and another bronze in épée. Breed was captain of the 1912 US Olympic fencing team. He fenced both foil and épée at the 1912 and 1924 Olympics. Breed was inducted into the Harvard Varsity Club Hall of Fame in 1972.

name: Audun Endestad
description: Audun Endestad was born in Norway but emigrated to the United States. He has always lived in Alaska, where he has become known as a big game guide, scout, and packer. He won 13 US titles in cross-country skiing and has won the Great American Ski Chase title six times. Endestad continues to compete in many sports at the masters level, including cross-country skiing, hiking, running, canoeing, cycling, and mountain climbing. Endestad married Judy Rabinowitz, who was also a cross-country skier on the 1984 US Olympic team.
special_notes: Husband (divorced) of Judy Rabinowitz Husband of Sally Zack

name: Jean Oldroyd
description: Jean Oldroyd had the following podium finishes at major championships: 1st in the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games 4×110 yards Medlay Relay (with Anita Lonsbrough, Margaret Edwards, and the non-Olymian Anne Marshall). In the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games 110 yards butterfly Oldroyd finished fifth. In the British Empire and Commonwealth Games she competed for England.

name: Aleksandar Varbanov
description: Aleksandar Varbanov had the following podium finishes at major championships: 3rd in the 1988 Olympics Middleweight class (332.5 kg); 1st in the 1983 World Championships Middleweight class (370.0 kg); 1st in the 1985 World Championships Middleweight class (370.0 kg); 1st in the 1986 World Championships Middleweight class (377.5 kg); 2nd in the 1987 World Championships Middleweight class (365.0 kg); 1st in the 1983 European Championships Middleweight class (370.0 kg); 2nd in the 1984 European Championships Middleweight class; 1st in the 1985 European Championships Middleweight class (360.0 kg); 1st in the 1986 European Championships Middleweight class (372.5 kg); 1st in the 1987 European Championships Middleweight class (370.0 kg); 2nd in the 1989 European Championships Middleweight class (350.0 kg). He set 12 world records in the lightweight and middleweight class – seven in the clean & jerk, and five in the total.

name: Richard Nowakowski
description: Richard Nowakowski was an East German boxer who played football as a youth. One of his youth coaches was Fritz Sdunek, now a well-known, successful boxing coach, who helped him to win the East German Youth Championship in 1969, 1971, and 1973. In 1974, Nowakowski won his first East German championship as an adult boxer, he was runner-up in 1975, and won again in 1976. At the Olympic Games in Montréal he lost the featherweight final against Cuban Ángel Herrera. Four years later he won a bronze medal in the lightweight division, becoming the only East German boxer to win two Olympic medals. Between the Games Nowakowski was 1977 European Championship and placed third in 1979. He was again East German Champion in 1978-79 and 1981. After his retirement in 1983 East German sports administrators recognized Richard Nowakowski as having “Western contacts” – his grandmother and other relatives were living in Stuttgart. After he had lost his semifinal at the 1982 World Championships in München against Adolfo Horta he had visited his relatives without giving notice to administrators. After he returned to the team the next day, the East German Stasi focused on him, he had difficulty finding a job, and he was not given a house that had been promised to him. In 1989 his grandmother celebrated her 75th birthday, Nowakowski requested a departure to West Germany to see her, and while sitting on the train he decided not to return to East Germany. His wife and his two daughters were pressured by the Stasi until German reunification. In 1989 Nowakowski won the West German lightweight championship against Jörg Kästner, but Kästner protested the decision and refused his congratulations. Even West German administrators claimed “What will happen if defector East German boxers win our titles?” Although the West German Champion, Nowakowski was not chosen for the World Championships at Moskva, and he was no longer welcome in East or West Germany. In 1993 he returned to his home town Schwerin where he made his living as a waste and recycling entrepreneur and grew wealthy in real estate.

name: Bill Allen
description: Bill Allen was originally an alternate on the 1972 Olympic team, but at the Games he was chosen to join Bill Bentsen as crew for Buddy Melges and between them they won the Olympic Soling class by a handsome margin. Allen won a national title in the 1970 E Scow class and was 1972 National Champion in the Finn class. He graduated from Colorado College in 1971 with a degree in business administration.

name: Alan Rice
description: Alan Rice wrestling for the University of Minnesota, winning two Big 10 titles in 1948 and 1949. He also made All-American in his senior year of college, when he captained the Gophers’ wrestling team. Wrestling primarily Greco-Roman after college, Rice placed fifth at the 1954 World Championships and won a silver medal as a featherweight at the 1955 Pan American Games. In 1956 he won AAU titles in both freestyle and Greco. After the 1956 Olympics Rice became a wrestling coach, founding the Minnesota Amateur Wrestling Club (later the Gopher Wrestling Club). He coached the US Greco-Roman wrestlers at the 1972 Olympics. He is a member of the National Wrestling Hall of Fame, University of Minnesota ‘M’ Club Hall of Fame, the Minnesota Wrestling Hall of Fame, and the Helms Hall of Fame
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1955 Ciudad de México WRE silver: freestyle featherweight -62 kg)

name: Henry Macintosh
description: The son of a vicar, Henry Macintosh, who was educated at Glenalmond College, where he became the first boy to win the athletics Challenge Cup three years in succession. He then went up to Corpus Christi, Cambridge, but had a poor domestic season prior to the 1912 Olympic Games. He lost to Duncan Macmillan in the 100 yards at the Cambridge University sports and in the match against Oxford, and at the AAA Championships he finished last in his 100 yards heat and did not run in the 220 yards. In Stockholm, he was eliminated in the heats of both sprints and 1912 would have been a very lean year had it not been for his Olympic gold medal in the sprint relay. In 1913, Macintosh was President of the Cambridge University AC and won the 100 yards against Oxford. His vastly improved form continued when he won the Scottish 100 yards title before equaling the British record of 9.8 seconds in Vienna. In 1914, he again won the 100 yards against Oxford before leaving to serve as an Assistant District Commission in South Africa after obtaining his B.A. from Cambridge in June that same year. After only a few months, the outbreak of war brought him home and he was commissioned into the 8th battalion, Argyll & Sutherland Highlanders. In the summer of 1918, Captain Macintosh was killed in action during the Second Battle of the Somme. Macintosh was also a fine rugby wing three-quarter, and played for the Cambridge XV. At the time of his death, his two brothers were both prisoners-of-war in Germany. Personal Bests: 100y – 9.8 (1913); 100 – 10.7 (1913); 200 – 22.1 (1913).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Were Killed or Missing in Action or Died as a Result of War (†26 July 1918. Died from wounds sustained in the Second Battle of the Somme.)

name: Luc Biquet
description: Luc Biquet won back-to-back Belgian amateur boxing titles in 1927 (bantamweight) and 1928 (featherweight). A native of Liège, he was the younger brother of noted amateur and professional boxer Nicolas Biquet (1907–1959), best known by his ring name “Petit Biquet”. One of four Liège-based boxers selected to represent Belgium at the 1928 Amsterdam Olympic Games, Luc Biquet defeated competitors from Germany and Poland before losing a decision to Víctor Peralta of Argentina in the semi final. In the ensuing bronze medal match, Biquet was defeated by Harry Devine of the United States. Following the Olympics, Biquet competed as a professional for close to two decades, until 1944. His record was 36 wins (8 by KO), 14 losses (2 by KO) and 6 ties.

name: Czesław Marchewczyk
description: Czesław Marchewczyk was Polish Champion in 1937, 1946 and 1947 with KS Cracovia. 1929-1948 he played 66 international matches for Poland scoring 20 goals. He also took part in five World Ice Hockey Championships (1930, 1935, 1937 - 1939). In 1930 and 1933 he also became Polish champion in handball earning one cap in this sport in 1935. Marchewczyk graduated as a civil engineer in 1949 in Cracow and was later involved in the construction of artificial skating rinks. 1957 - 1967 he belonged to the board of the Polish Ice Hockey Association. He received numerous awards for his merits.

name: Samuel Lagonia
description: Samuel Lagonia represented the Bronxdale Athletic Club, winning the AAU title in 1919-21 as a middleweight. In 1919 Lagonia won three Metropolitan AAU titles in the same night, winning bouts as a middleweight, light-heavy, and heavyweight. At the 1920 Olympics, Lagonia was considered a medal favorite, but had the misfortune to meet Britain’s redoubtable Harry Mallin in the quarter-finals, and Mallin eliminated Lagonia. After his 1921 AAU title, Lagonia turned professional but had a short career. He won four bouts, two by knockout, and never lost, but there is no record of him fighting after October 1921.

name: Reino Hiltunen
description: Triple jumper Reino Hiltunen represented Finland internationally 11 times between 1948 and 1953, although he never won a major international medal. His most notable appearance, therefore, came at the 1952 Helsinki Olympics, where he finished ninth in a field of 35 competitors. He won the Finnish National Championship in this discipline in 1948 and 1951, came in second in 1952 and 1953, and was third in 1950. He was also third nationally in the long jump in 1950. After retiring in 1955, he served as a coach for the remainder of the decade and was later involved in local sports administration. Personal Best: TJ – 15.24 (1951).

name: Eric Dutton
description: Eric Dutton started his lacrosse career as a third home, but later played at third man. In addition to playing in the 1908 Olympics, he won representative honours with Lancashire, England and the North, in the annual match against the South, which was regarded a one of the leading lacrosse fixtures at the time. He also represented Lancashire against the touring Canadians in 1907. Dutton served on the executive committee of the North of England Lacrosse Association.

name: Frank Jewett
description: Frank Jewett sailed in the one-person dinghy class at the 1936 Olympics. He sailed mostly out of the Southern Massachusetts Yacht Racing Association (SMYRA). Jewett was a leader in the administration of that club and was instrumental in changing many of the rules of sailing to their modern formats. In 1965 he persuaded the North American Yacht Racing Union (NAYRU) to restore the Prince of Wales bowl as the perpetual trophy for the SMYRA interclub match racing championship. Jewett had won the Prince of Wales bowl in 1934, 1935, and 1937, along with Kingman Brewster, Jr., and they had retired the trophy.

name: Rudolf Baier
description: Rudolf Baier finished 27th in the 315 km individual road race at the 1912 Stockholm Olympics, which was held as an individual time trial. This helped Germany finish sixth in the team road race in 1912, as he was among the four best German finishers. Germany had all 11 team members finish the race, the only nation to do so.

name: Francesco Antonazzi
description: Francesco Antonazzi played for SS Lazio Roma from 1946-56, always in the Italian Serie A. He was a defender who played in 251 league matches but never scored. Antonazzi was an alternate at the 1948 Olympics. He twice played for the B National Team, in matches in May 49 against Turkey and Egypt. Antonazzi later coached youth teams with SS Lazio and in 1963/64 he was an assistant coach for the SS Lazio senior team.

name: Ivan Lebanov
description: At the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, Ivan Lebanov became Bulgaria’s first Winter Olympic medallist, winning a bronze medal in the 30 km. This came as a major surprise, having previously achieved only modest international results, with the exception of becoming World Junior Champion in 1977, and World Student Championships in 1978 and 1981. Capturing multiple national titles in all distances, Lebanov was elected Bulgarian winter athlete of the 20th century. After his active career, Lebanov was active as an administrator in both the Bulgarian Olympic Committee and the Bulgarian Skiing Federation. He also became involved in politics, and in 2007 he was elected mayor of Velingrad, the town in which he grew up.

name: Lauri Silvennoinen
description: Lauri Silvennoinen made his international début at the 1938 World Championship, where he was 32nd at 18 km. At the 1941 World Championships he won a gold medal as a member of the Finnish relay team and a bronze in the 18 km. In 1943 he won his first two Finnish titles – in 18 km and in relay – and also won gold in the 18 km and silver in the 50 km at the Lahti Ski Games, his only medals at that competition. In 1944 Silvennoinen again won two Finnish titles, this time at 30 km and again in the relay. His last two Finnish titles came in 1947 and 1948, both in the relay. Silvennoinen made his last international appearance at the 1948 Winter Olympics, where he skied the first leg of the silver medal winning Finnish relay team. After his sporting career he worked with the Finnish Skiing Federation in various positions and was a member of the Lahti Ski Games Executive Board. Silvennoinen was also a sergeant of both the Finnish Police and Finnish Security Police.

name: Senee Kongtong
description: Senee Kongtong has been in the Thai 4×400 m team on six occations between 1998 and 2003, including the Olympics in 2000. The team did 3:05.89 for a fifth place in the Asian Championship 2000, but was not able to do better than 3.11 in Sydney. Kongtong has run the 400 m on three occations in Asian Championships or Games, but have never been able to advance further than to the semi-final. Personal Best: 400 – 47.25 (2000).

name: Ferry Dedovich
description: Austrian figure skater Ferry Dedovich partnered Inge Strell at the 1964 Innsbruck Winter Olympics, when the pair finished 15th. In 1963 and 1965 they also participated at the European Championships but, again, with little success. In 1966 Dedovich partnered non-Olympian Evelyn Scharf and they finished 15th, again, at the Europeans. Dedovich later turned to coaching at EC Regensburg in Germany.
