name: Gianni Caldana
description: Gianni Caldana was a sprinter/jumper who first joined G. A. Padovano, but later moved to Assi Giglio Rosso in Firenze. On 14 July 1936 Caldana set an Italian record of 7.50 in the long jump, but could not duplicate that at the Berlin Olympics, where he finished 12th. The highlight of his career was his silver medal in the 4x100 relay at Berlin. He later helped Italy to a fourth-place relay finish at the 1938 European Championships. Caldan became a coach after he retired from athletics, leading the 1964 Olympic finalist Sergio Ottolina. He also worked as an athletic trainer, notably with football clubs such as AC Fiorentina, AC Milan and Atalanta Bergamasca. Personal Bests: 100 – unknown; 110H – 14.7 (1940); LJ – 7.50 (1936).

name: Apolo Anton Ohno
description: Born to a Japanese father and an American mother, Apolo Anton Ohno had a troublesome youth, but his parents used his skating talent to straighten him out. After winning the 1999 World Junior title, Ohno soon rose to the international top, winning the 2001 1500 m World title. A crowd favourite at the 2002 Olympics in Salt Lake City, he won two medals, both of them after eventful races. His 1500 m gold was gained after the controversial disqualification of Kim Dong-Seong for cross-tracking. In the 1000 m, four out of five finalists fell in the final lap, allowing Steven Bradbury to win. Ohno managed to quickly crawl over the finish line to win the silver. Four years later, Ohno won three more Olympic medals, including the title in the 500 m. In 2008, he won the overall world title, after having won five distance titles earlier in his career. Ohno also won the World Cup three times (2001, 2003, 2005).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Short Track Speed Skating Championships (8–6–6 2001 Jeonju gold: 3000 m and 5000 m relay, silver: 1000 m and Allround; 2003 Warszawa silver: 3000 m; 2005 Beijing gold: 1000 m and 3000 m, silver: Allround, bronze: 5000 m relay; 2007 Milano gold: 1500 m, bronze: 1000 m, 3000 m, Allround, and 5000 m relay; 2008 Gangneung gold: 500 m and Allround, silver: 1000 m, bronze: 3000 m; 2009 Wien gold: 5000 m relay, silver: 1000 m) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Short Track Speed Skating Team Championships (1–0–1 2008 Harbin gold; 2009 Heerenveen bronze)

name: Gürbüz Lü
description: Gürbüz Lü had the following finishes at major championships – 1973 World Championship: 100.0 kg. Greco-Roman (5th); 1969 European Championship: 100.0 kg. Greco-Roman (4th); 1966 European Championship: 97.0 kg. Greco-Roman (6th).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–0–0 1971 İzmir WRE gold: Greco-Roman heavyweight -100 kg)

name: Sergio Paganella
description: Born in Libiola, a small village of the municipality of Serravalle a Po, Sergio Paganella moved to Milano as a youngster, and in 1930 played for his first basketball club, Società Sportiva Santo Stefano. After joining the Milano Borletti club, he won four Italian titles (1936-39) and got the chance to play in the national team. With the “Azzurri” he played at the 1935 European Championships, the Olympics in 1936, and the 1937 Europeans in Latvia, where he won the silver medal. Paganella’s sporting career was put on hold during World War II while he served with the Battaglione San Marco. After the war he resumed his sporting activities and, in addition to basketball, played water polo, tennis, boxing and gymnastics. In 1935, he graduated in economics and worked for the Borletti group, and then opened a small firm of sanitary facilities, which he ran until 1986.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Basketball Championship (EuroBasket) (0–1–0 1937 LAT silver)

name: Acke Åslund
description: Acke Åslund was a painter and printmaker. He studied at the Technical School in Stockholm (from 1900) and the Art Academy (from 1904), also in Stockholm. He also attended the famous etching course of Axel Tallberg. Later Åslund travelled to Germany, France and Spain. He was primarily known for depicting horses, which are found in his drawings and paintings. At the Veterinary College he studied horse anatomy, and lived for long periods near the North Swedish horse center, Vången’s Stallion Breeding Center in Jämtland. Åslund’s paintings carry an air of impressionism. He was a member of the Artists National Organization, the Swedish Artists Association, the Graphic Society and the Artists’ Club in Stockholm. His chalk drawings are more highly regarded than his oil paintings. There are at least three known drawings or prints by Åslund with the title Travhästar (Trotting Horses) produced between 1915 and 1920. The largest part of his estate is in the Provincial Museum of Jämtland.

name: Humberto Briceño
description: Humberto Briceño had the following podium finishes at major championships: 3rd in the 1955 Pan American Games 300 m high power rifle 3 positions team (with Juan Llabot, Rigoberto Rivero, and the non-Olympians John López and José P. Váldez).
special_notes: Brother of Germán Briceño Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1955 Ciudad de México SHO bronze: free rifle 3 positions team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–1–0 1954 Ciudad de México SHO silver: 50 m small-bore rifle 3 positions)

name: Andy Gilpin
description: Prior to World War II, Andy Gilpin was an ice hockey right winger with the Montreal Westmount of the Quebec Junior Hockey League. When the conflict broke out he joined the Royal Canadian Air Force and served on the Aleutian Islands. While at home, he played hockey with the Victoria and Vancouver RCAF Seahawks, although after the war he was stationed in Whitehorse, Yukon. It was during his service here that he was selected, in 1947, to help represent Canada 1948 Winter Olympic ice hockey tournament. His nation captured gold, but Gilpin did not play due to an ankle injury, although he later received a medal. After the Games he was affiliated with the Arnprior Greenshirts of the Rideau Hockey League, but elected to pursue his military career rather than attempt to make a living as a professional hockey player. He served with the RCAF as a specialist in instruments and electrics prior to his retirement with the rank of chief warrant officer in 1975. He continued to play hockey for many decades, however, and was skating weekly until his death from a heart attack at the age of 93, despite having broken his hip and shoulder on the ice in his late 80s.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (1–0–0 1948 St. Moritz (Olympics) gold)

name: Doris Batter
description: Doris Batter took up running to help improve her speed as a hockey player, and within 12 months found herself at the 1948 London Olympic Games. She won her opening heat in the 100 metres, but was then drawn in a semi-final containing Fanny Blankers-Koen and Shirley Strickland, the eventual gold and bronze medalists, and she failed to qualify for the final. Batter went to the Olympics as a member of London Olympiades, the oldest women’s athletic club in Britain, formed in 1921. She also went to the Games as the reigning WAAA 60 metres champion, a title she retained in 1949. Batter represented England at the 1950 Empire Games and, despite finishing fifth in her respective heats in the individual 100 and 220 yards, won a silver medal in the 660 yards relay along with Dorothy Hall, Sylvia Cheeseman and Margaret Walker. After the Games, Cheeseman and Batter were banned from representative athletics for a year by the Women’s AAA, because they were: “Not amenable to discipline during the Games”. The ban barely lasted two months, when they were cleared after an appeal. A keen squash player, Batter married the useful half-miler Len Hatton in the summer of 1951. Personal Best: 100y – 11.1 (1949).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 1950 Auckland ATH silver: 220-110-220-110 yards relay (competed for England))

name: Nataliya Meshcheryakova
description: Nataliya Meshcheryakova won her only major international title, in the 50 metre freestyle, at her last international tournament, the 1997 European Championships. Meshcheryakova made her international début at the 1992 Olympics, where she won bronze in the medley relay and was sixth in the 50 free. At the 1993 European Championships Meshcheryakova won silver in the medley relay and bronze in the 4x100 freestyle relay while unfortunately placing fourth in both the 50 and 100 freestyles. At the 1994 World Championships Meshcheryakova won silver in the 50 free and was again a member of the bronze medal-winning Russian medley relay team. Meshcheryakova did not medal at the 1996 Olympics, placing eighth in the 50 freestyle and, at the 1997 European Championships, in addition to her 50 freestyle title, she won silver in the medley relay and bronze in the 4x100 freestyle relay. Domestically, Meshcheryakova won the Russian 50 and 100 metre freestyle titles from 1993-97. Meshcheryakova retired from sports at the end of 1997 and later married Vlad Pyshnenko, who won a 4x200 freestyle relay gold at the 1992 Olympics. Personal Best: 50 m freestyle – 25.10 (1994); 100 m freestyle – 55.58 (1994).

name: Ulrich Mense
description: Ulrich Mense and Wilfried Lorenz sailed with skipper Peter Ahrendt on the East German Dragon class yacht Mutafo. They did not start well at the 1964 Olympic races near Enoshima Island on Sagami Bay, when they finished 8th, 10th and 7th in their first three races, but after finishing first in their fourth race and twice second and once fourth in the remaining three races, it was enough to win a silver medal behind the Danish crew. The same Empor Rostock club sailing crew also won East German Dragon class titles from 1960-63 and 1965, and won silvers at the 1966 and 1967 East German championships. Mense entered the board of his home club Empor Rostock after his active sailing career. By profession, he was an economic engineer in a fishery combine at Rostock.

name: Solonei da Silva
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 2011 Guadalajara ATH gold: marathon)

name: Leopold Treffny
description: Austrian lightweight weightlifter Leopold Treffny set two world records in the middleweight clean & jerk in 1925 and 1927. He finished an unfortunate fourth at the 1924 Paris Olympics with the same result as the Czech Bohumil Durdis, who took the bronze medal because he weighed 500 grams less than Treffny. Treffny finished fifth at the 1923 World Championships. He also won the 1925 International Czech Championships and finished second at the German Fighting Games the following year. Domestically, Treffny won Austrian national titles in 1923-25, and the Wiener (Vienna) Championships in 1926. He emigrated to Argentina in 1929, and died at Buenos Aires.

name: Czesław Białas
description: Czesław Białas had the following podium finishes at major championships: 3rd in the 1959 World Championships Middle-Heavyweight class (422.5 kg); 3rd in the 1955 European Championships Light-Heavyweight class (385.0 kg); 1st in the 1957 European Championships Middle-Heavyweight class (420.0 kg); 3rd in the 1959 European Championships Middle-Heavyweight class (422.5 kg).

description: Also played cricket for Rhodesia.

name: Stev Theloke
description: German backstroke and IM swimmer Stev Theloke won bronze medals at the 2000 Sydney Olympics in the 100 metres backstroke and 4x100 IM relay. Four years earlier in Atlanta, he reached the B-finals over 100 metres backstroke (14th) and 200 metres IM (12th). Theloke also swam the heats with the 4x100 IM relay. In 1998, he won the 100 metres backstroke bronze medal at the World Championships. At European Championships Theloke was even more successful, winning ten golds (among them seven individual titles over 50 and 100 metres backstroke), seven silver and four bronze medals. In 2005, Theloke was banned from the national team, and the World Championships, due to critical comments about the German Swimming Association. At German Championships, he won a total of 19 national titles. Theloke was awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, Germany’s highest sports award. By profession, he became a personal trainer and swimming coach at Chemnitz.

name: Oliver Gussenberg
description: German extra-lightweight judoka Oliver Gussenberg was eliminated in the pool stage at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. Four years later at Athens he finished joint seventh. In 1997 and 2007, he won his only two German national titles. By profession, Gussenberg became a graduated researcher with an internationally active market research institute and became self-employed in the field of sports marketing and opinion research in 2007.

name: Yoshihide Fukutome
description: Japanese modern pentathlete Yoshihide Fukutome competed at his home Olympics in Tokyo in 1964. Fukutome had good results in shooting (5th), running (7th), and equestrian (10th), but poor results in swimming and fencing dropped him down to 17th place at the end of the five events. His individual results helped the Japanese team to finish in eighth place overall.

name: Motohiko Ban
description: Motohiko Ban was the first Japanese ski jumper to compete in Europe. He won the ski jumping at the All-Japan Ski Championships in 1926 and in 1929 at the Students’ Championships. Later he became a sports official as president of the All-Japan Student Ski Federation in 1972 and chairman of the All-Japan Ski Federation 1975-1986. He served as head of the Lake Placid Japanese Olympic team in 1980 and received the Olympic Order in silver four years later. Although born in Kyoto, his family moved to Otaru on the northern island of Hokkaido when he was a child, after his father had been appointed director of the local commercial school. Ban attended the Hokkaido Imperial University Faculty of Agriculture and started working for Nippon Flour Milling Co., Ltd. in 1929. From manager he was promoted to vice-president, president and ultimately, in 1974, chairman. He died six months after the Nagano Winter Olympics in 1998.

name: Jean Heeremans
description: Jean Heeremans was an eight-time Belgian champion but after World War II he emigrated to the United States where he became the fencing coach at Southern Cal and the Los Angeles Athletic Club. In the US he changed his name and went by Heremans. In 1948 Heremans was hired by MGM to supervise the duels for their remake of “The Three Musketeers.” This led to a career in which he frequently choreographed duels and also appeared in several movies, often uncredited, including “The Three Musketeers,” “The Last Time I Saw Paris,” “Singing in the Rain,” and “Northwest Passage.”
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Acted in Movies (11 credits on IMDb from 1948-61)

name: Pierre Devaux
description: Pierre Devaux was a Belgian long-distance runner who represented Union Athlétique de Bruxelles. In 1919 Devaux was the national champion in the 10,000 metres and set a national record that stood until the following year. He ran in the same event at the 1920 Antwerpen Olympics but was eliminated in the opening heat. Personal Best: 10,000 – 34:19.2 (1919).

name: Lloyd Johnson
description: Tebbs Lloyd Johnson was a remarkable competitor who remained in the top flight for 25 years. After placing third in the RWA 20 miles walk in 1923, he won the title in 1927, 1931, and 1934, and was the 50K champion in 1931, 1934, and 1949. At the 1948 Olympics he won a bronze medal and, at 48 years, 115 days, he became the oldest Olympic medalist in an athletics event. His best performance came in the 1936 RWA 50K when he crossed the line 4 seconds ahead of future Olympic champion Harold Whitlock, but was disqualified for lifting in the closing stages of a dramatic finish. His time was not bettered by a British walker for 20 years. He succeeded Whitlock as National Coach and served as RWA President 1970-71. Personal Bests: 20kmW – 1-37:55.4 (1934); 20 mile Walk – 2-47:22.0 (1930); 50kmW – 4-36:02.0 (1948).

name: Kasey Keller
description: Kasey Keller was a goalkeeper who played at the University of Portland. He led the team to the NCAA Final Four as a freshman and in 1991 was named the adidas Goalkeeper of the year. While in school he played at the U-20 World Cup, earning the Silver Ball as the second best player in the tournament. Keller quickly moved up to the USA National Team and was on the team at the 1990 World Cup, although he did not play. He then signed with the English club Millwall and played for them from 1990-96, joining Leicester City at the end of that season. Keller was with Leicester City through 1999, and then joined the Spanish club Rayo Vallecano, playing there until 2001. He returned to England in 2001, with Tottenham Hotspur, staying there through the 2005 season, although he spent part of 2004 on loan to Southampton. Keller played in Germany next, with Borussia Mönchengladbach, but in 2007 went back to England, this time with Fulham. He ended his career with three seasons in Major League Soccer (MLS), with the Seattle Sounders, retiring after the 2011 season. Internationally, Keller played at the 1998 World Cup and the 1996 Olympics. He was again on the US Team at the 2002 and 2006 World Cups, making Claudio Reyna and him the first two Americans to make four World Cup squads. Keller was US Soccer Athlete of the Year in 1997, 1999, and 2005, and helped the US win the CONCACAF Gold Cup in 2002, 2005, and 2007. He was capped 102 times with 53 wins in goal, and was the 10th American to record 100 caps. He also recorded 47 clean sheets during his career, the most famous coming in a 1998 upset victory over Brazil in the CONCACAF Gold Cup, when he had 10 saves, many from point blank range. Keller was inducted into the US Soccer Hall of Fame in 2015. After his playing career he was an assistant manager for the US U-20 team, and also coached the keepers for the US National Team.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1991 La Habana FTB gold)

name: Aleksandr Zavyalov
description: Aleksandr Zavyalov made his international début at the 1978 Winter Universiade, where he won golds in the 30 km and relay. Next Zavyalov competed at the 1980 Winter Olympics, where he won bronze at 50K and was seventh in the 15 km. In 1980-81 Zavyalov won the World Cup, which he repeated in 1982-83. In 1982 Zavyalov competed at his only World Championships and won a gold in the relay, was second in the 15 km and was sixth at both 30 and 50 km. Zavyalov made his last international appearance at the 1984 Winter Olympics where he won silvers in both the 30 km and relay, was seventh at 50 km and 16th in the 15 km. Domestically Zavyalov won three Soviet titles – in 1983 at 30 km and in 1979 and 1982 in the relay. After his sporting career Zavyalov worked as a sports administrator and later served as President of the Russian Skiing Federation.

name: Michael Douglass
description: Michael Douglass was a sport shooter who competed in air pistol at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. He was 2000 USA Champion in the event and won the air pistol at the 2000 Toronto Air Gun Championships. Douglass started out as a rifle shooter but switched to pistol after college and also shot free pistol. He later worked for the US Olympic Committee in drug control administration.

name: Carl Hallsthammar
description: Swedish-American sculptor Carl Hallsthammar was born as Karl Emil Andersson in Sweden, where he started his studies in Mora/Dalarna. He immigrated into the United States in June 1923, where he changed his name to Carl Hallsthammar, in honor of his hometown Hallstahammar, but with one “a” missing. He settled in Chicago, Illinois, where he completed his studies at the Art Institute and founded his own school for wood carving. Hallthammar became a specialist in wood sculptures (portrait busts and statues) and relief carvings.

name: Guo Yingqi
description: With Guo Yingqi, an overseas Chinese from Malaya on the team, Sing Tao won third place in Hong Kong’s Group A league in the 1939-40 season. For many seasons to follow, he joined the Kitchee SC. Guo was able to play center and inside forward positions as well as halfback. He was the top scorer of the Hong Kong league in the 1947-48 season, when Kitchee took the title. Unfortunately, he used to argue with his teammates, which made him difficult to play with. In some of the 22 matches he played during the tour of the Chinese football team to the 1948 London Olympics, Guo did not seem to be in his best shape and was not fielded in China’s only match at the Olympics.

name: Mitch Richmond
description: Mitch Richmond started college at Moberly Area Community College but played for Kansas State University from 1986-88. He was second-team All-American in 1988. Richmond was the 5th overall pick of the 1988 NBA Draft, chosen by the Golden State Warriors. Richmond played in the NBA for 14 years, playing with the Warriors through 1991, and then was with the Sacramento Kings from 1991-98. He was with the Washington Wizards from 1998-2001 and finished his career with a single season with the Los Angeles Lakers. In his NBA career, Richmond averaged 21.0 ppg, and finished with 20,497 points, and was considered one of the league’s best pure shooters. He was a six-time NBA All-Star, a five-time All-NBA Team member and was NBA Rookie of the Year for the 1988/89 season. Richmond’s #2 was retired by the Sacramento Kings. Internationally Richmond won a gold medal at the 1996 Olympics and a bronze medal at the 1988 Olympics. He also won a silver medal at the 1987 Universiade. In 2014, Richmond was inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.

name: Haruyoshi Nakagawa
description: Before Haruyoshi Nakagawa joined the University of Tokyo, he was wearing the colors of the Hachiko Rowing Club, the club of the 8th High School in Nagoya. In World War II, he served as a medical officer. In 1954, Nakagawa published his thesis under the title “Clinical study of paralysis”.

name: Tara Lipinski
description: Tara Lipinski started out as a roller skater, but started figure skating by the time she was six. In 1995 she was second at the US Junior Figure Skating Championships, and placed fourth that year at the World Juniors, aged only 12. In 1996 she disappointed somewhat, placing fifth at the World Juniors. But in 1996 she moved up to the senior level, and was third at the US Championships, qualifying her for the World team. In 1996, the International Skating Union raised the minimum age for World Championship competition to 15, but Lipinski was grandfathered in, placing 15th. Lipinski’s big breakthrough year was 1997, as she won both the US and World Championships, upsetting Michelle Kwan at both events. However, in the 1997-98 season, Kwan regained her dominance, defeating Lipinski at Skate America and the US Chamionships, and Lipinski also lost at Trophée Lalique, and Kwan entered the Nagano Olympics as the favorite. But Lipinski shone in the free skate at Nagano, landing seven triples, including a triple loop-triple loop combination, to win the gold medal, with Kwan second. Shortly after the 1998 Winter Olympics, Lipinski turned professional, skating for four years with Stars on Ice. She later became well known in the US as a commentator on televised figure skating competitions.

name: Michaela Herweck
description: West German diver Michaela Herweck was eliminated in the qualification round at the 1972 München Olympics in the women’s springboard event. From 1965-74 she was on the West German national team and won the 1972 springboard national title. She later graduated as a sports teacher and diving coach. Herweck then coached divers at München together with her husband Beppo.

name: Jan Krzesiak
description: Jan Krzesiak had the following finishes at major championships – 1995 World Championship: 62.0 kg. Freestyle (27th); 1993 European Championship: 62.0 kg. Freestyle (4th); 1996 European Championship: 62.0 kg. Freestyle (8th); 1995 European Championship: 62.0 kg. Freestyle (11th).

name: Jeanne Vaussard
description: Jeanne Vaussard competed in both singles and doubles at the 1920 and 1924 Olympics. Born Jeanne G. Beaudry, she married André Vaussard, a French tournament referee. Vaussard was French Covered Court champion in ladies’ doubles in 1921 and mixed doubles in 1920. She entered Wimbledon in 1929 but withdrew from her first round matches in singles and doubles.

name: Ron Snook
special_notes: Brother of Emmy Snook

name: George Mattson
description: George Mattson rowed at West Catholic High School in Philadelphia, helping them to win the Stotesbury Cup on the Schuylkill River. He then rowed for the Penn AC crew and in 1932 helped the coxless fours crew to the NAAO (National Association of Amateur Oarsmen) Championship, which qualified them for the 1932 Olympics, where they finished fourth. He later coached schoolboy rowing on Boat House Row, then became crew coach at West Catholic High School, and was instrumental in founding the rowing program at St. Joseph’s College. From 1958-70 Mattson coached crew at Monsignor Bonner High School. He also worked a day job as manager of the Red Lion moving and storage company. Mattson was a member of the Undine Barge Club and was inducted into the West Catholic, Pennsylvania and Delaware County Sports Halls of Fame.

name: George Buckley
description: George Buckley was one of several members of the Castle Cary cricket club who played in the Paris match. He batted only in the first innings and scored two runs. Of the 22 French dismissals only five were caught, and Buckley claimed one of them, when he held Robert Horne off the bowling of Frederick Christian, when on 15 in France’s first innings.

name: Jim Blair
description: Jim Blair went to Cal/Berkeley. In 1928 he rowed the seventh seat for their crew which won the Intercollegiate Rowing Association (IRA) Regatta and, after graduation, was on their eight-oared shell which won the gold at the Los Angeles Olympics. Blair was the smallest oarsman in the eight, weighing only 168 lb. (76 kg.). He went into the packaging industry.

name: Adolfo Corsi
description: A good track sprint cyclist, Adolfo Corsi was unlucky at the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics, finishing fourth in the tandem sprint with Francesco Malatesta. Corsi also competed in the sprint at the world championships that year but was eliminated in the quarter-finals. In 1929, he won the Italian sprint title but never obtained any further significant wins after that.

name: Lynn Nelson
description: Lynn Nelson was a distance runner who ran the 10,000 metres at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, finishing 15th. Nelson won the 1988 US Olympic Trials to make the team. At the US Championships she finished second in the 10K in 1986 and third in 1987. Nelson also ran marathons. She was ranked in the US top 10 four times in the 10K, ranking second in 1986-87, and was 10th ranked in the US in the marathon in 1988. She was world ranked one time in the 10,000, as #10 in 1988. Personal Best: 10000 – 31:51.27 (1988).

name: Charles Davis
description: Charles Davis shot running target for the United States at the 1972 Olympics. Davis started shooting as a youngster in the Eastern Kentucky hills, beginning with a slingshot, then a BB gun, and progressing to rifle shooting. A Kentucky native, he spent a career in the military, serving in both Korea and Vietnam. He joined the US Navy after leaving high school, but moved to the US Army. and started shooting rifle with the 34th Infantry Regiment in 1954. He then spent 21 years with the US Army Marksmanship Unit. Davis graduated from Centre College of Danville, Kentucky in 1952. Davis was US Champion in running target in 1972 and also won the Interservice Title in running target that year. He was 1961 US Champion with the military rifle. He competed at multiple internationals for the United States from 1956-82, including the 1960 and 1968 CISM Championships. He earned his Distinguished Rifleman Badge in 1957, won the Daniel Boone Trophy in 1959, and was the National Service Rifle Champion in 1961. In 1968 he became the only shooter to win both the Wimbledon and Leech Cups in the same year, and in 1971 he again won the Wimbledon Cup. In 1973 he earned his International Distinguished Badge. Davis earned numerous awards and medals, including the Combat Infantryman Badge, the Expert Infantry Badge, President’s Hundred Tab, Bronze Star, Meritorious Service Medal, Army Commendation Medal with two oak leaf clusters, Good Conduct Medal (seven), American Area Ribbon, WWII Victory Medal, National Defense Service Medal, Vietnam Service Medal with three bronze stars, Vietnam Campaign Medal, Vietnamese Cross of Gallantry with Palm and Vietnam Civil Actions Unit Citation.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (0–1–1 1974 Bern/Thun bronze: 50 m running target team; 1978 Seoul silver: 50 m running target team)

name: Vilar Santos
description: Personal Best: Dec – 6266 (1960).

name: Jahangir Butt
description: Jahangir Butt played hockey for Pakistan at the 1968 and 1972 Olympic Games, winning gold in 1968 and silver in 1972. He also helped Pakistan win gold at the 1970 Asian Games and silver at the 1966 Asian Games. In his professional life, Jahangir Butt worked with the Pakistan Customs Department and retired as a superintendent of customs.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–1–0 1966 Bangkok HOC silver; 1970 Bangkok HOC gold)

name: Hatsuko Morioka
description: Hatsuko Morioka was a five-time Japanese champion in the 400 m freestyle (1931-33, 1935-36) but also excelled in the backstroke. After retiring from competitive sports, she joined Nippon Life Insurance Co. and married in 1940.

name: Uwe Steingroß
description: East German sailor Uwe Steingroß partnered with Jörg Schramme at the 1976 Montréal Olympics in the Olympic Yachting Center at Kingston, Ontario and at the 1980 Olympics when the sailing events were held in Tallinn in Estonia. At Kingston they were in the Flying Dutchman class and finished 15th. At Tallinn they then moved to the Tornado multi-hull boat class and placed eighth. In 1976 and 1979 they won the nationals with the Flying Dutchman. Steingroß was trained as a metal cutter mechanic and studied sports at the DHfK Leipzig. After re-unification he founded his own company producing precision parts for high-tech equipment used in space cameras or welding robots for automobile production.

name: Barbara Jensen
description: Barbara Jensen learned to swim at the Jewish Community Center in San Francisco. At age 12, she swam for the Crystal Plunge Pool in San Francisco and then went to Athens Athletic Club in Oakland, later to return to Crystal Plunge in 1949. Jensen broke the American record for the 100 metre backstroke in 1945 when only 15-years-old. She was an All-American swimmer from 1948-50 and was a member of the 1949-50 US overseas squads and was high point winner at the indoor and outdoor Nationals in 1949, winning the 1949 AAUs outdoors in the 110 yd and 220 yd backstroke, and indoors in the 220 yd backstroke. In 1949 she was runner-up for the Sullivan Award. After raising her family, Jensen returned to school and earned a Masters’ degree in Sociology at age 44 from Saint Xavier University in Chicago. In 1972 Jensen also returned to Masters’ Swimming while living near Chicago. She became an All-American Masters’ Swimmer from 1972-79, winning 42 national titles and setting eight age-group US or world records in the backstroke. She then took a break in 1980 for health reasons but returned to the pool for competition in 1997, winning her age-group in the 50, 100, and 200 backstroke in 1997, and again making the All-American Masters’ Swim team in 1997, and 2000-01.

name: Jeong Hae-Rim
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (1–0–1 2019 Krasnoyarsk SBD gold: parallel giant slalom, bronze: parallel slalom)

name: Rafer Johnson
description: Rafer Johnson made his decathlon début in 1954 and the next year won the Pan American Games title and set the first of his three world decathlon records. Johnson, who competed for UCLA and the Southern California Striders, won the AAU decathlon in 1956, 1958, and 1960 and after placing second to Milt Campbell at the 1956 Olympics, never lost another decathlon. He was injured at the 1956 Games, which forced him to withdraw from the Olympic long jump, for which he had also qualified. His three world decathlon records were set in 1955, 1958, and at the 1960 US Olympic Trials. Johnson’s Olympic gold medal was won dramatically in the final 1,500 over his UCLA college roommate, C. K. Yang of Chinese Taipei, who took the silver medal. Yang was close after nine events and was a better 1,500 metre runner, but Johnson followed closely behind him throughout the race, and would not let Yang pull away, enabling Johnson to win the gold. After his retirement in 1960 he acted in a few movies, and served for many years as a commercial spokesman for many products. The plaintiff cry moment’s after Robert Kennedy’s assassination was, “Get the gun, Rafer!,” and it was Rafer Johnson to whom the voice beckoned. Johnson and football star Rosey Grier were rabid Kennedy supporters and were standing next to him that fateful night, and they helped disarm the shooter. In 1984 Rafer Johnson was chosen to light the Olympic Flame at the Opening Ceremony of the Los Angeles Olympics. He also became a big supporter of Special Olympics, leading the Southern California chapter. His younger brother Jimmy played NFL football for 16 years with the San Francisco 49ers and was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1994. Rafer’s daughter, Jenny Johnson-Jordan, competed in beach volleyball at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. Personal Bests: 100 – 10.3 (1957); 220y – 21.0 (1956); 400 – 47.9 (1956); 110H – 13.8 (1956); HJ – 6-2½ (1.89) (1955); PV – 13-5¼ (4.09) (1960); LJ – 25-5½ (7.76) (1956); SP – 54-11½ (16.75) (1958); DT – 172-3 (52.50) (1960); JT – 251-9 (76.73) (1960); Dec – 7982 (1960).
special_notes: Father of Jenny Johnson-Jordan Torchbearer within the Olympic Stadium at the Opening Ceremony of the 1984 Summer Olympics (Lit flame) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1955 Ciudad de México ATH gold: decathlon) Listed in Olympians Involved in James Bond movies (Small role in "Licence to Kill" as a DEA agent) Listed in Olympians Who Acted in Movies (26 credits on IMDb from 1960-89.) Listed in Olympians Who Were Awarded the James E. Sullivan Award (1960) Listed in Olympians Who Were Named Sports Illustrated's Sportsman of the Year (Decathlon world record, 1958 Sports Illustrated Sportsman of the Year)

name: Ivano Brugnetti
description: Ivano Brugnetti won the 1999 world title in the 50 km walking, but did not receive his medal until November 2001, when Russian walker German Skurygin was disqualified for testosterone use. Brugnetti later focused on the 20 km, but initially without much success. Only at the 2004 Olympics did Brugnetti again rise to the top of the podium, winning the 20 km by a narrow margin of just 5 seconds. In addition to these international victories, he has also won five Italian titles, winning the 5 km indoor in 2001, the 10 km in 1999 and 2006, and the 20 km in 2003 and 2004. Personal Bests: 20kmW – 1-19:36 (2007); 50kmW – 3-47:54 (1999).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (1–0–0 1999 Sevilla gold: 50 km walk) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–0–0 2009 Pescara ATH gold: 20 km walk) Listed in Olympians Who Received the Italian Olympic Association (CONI) Gold Medal ()

name: Michael Senft
description: German whitewater canoeist Michael Senft partnered André Ehrenberg at the 1996 Atlanta and the 2000 Sydney Games. The pair won the bronze medal in the Canadian doubles in 1996, and finished eighth in 2000. In 2004 at Athens, Senft then partnered Christian Bahmannn and they finished an unfortunate fourth. At World Championships, Senft won a gold medal in 1995 with Bahmann, and three more silvers and two bronzes. At European Championships, he won a medal of each colour. Senft later became manager of the Regional Whitewater Olympic Center at Augsburg.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Slalom World Championships (1–3–2 1995 Nottingham bronze: C2 team; 1997 Três Coroas silver: C2, bronze: C2 team; 2002 Bourg St.-Maurice silver: C2 team; 2003 Augsburg silver: C2 team; 2005 Penrith gold: C2 and C2 team (non-medal event)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Canoe Slalom Championships (1–1–1 1996 Augsburg gold: C2 team; 2000 Mezzana gold: C2 team (non-medal event); 2002 Bratislava bronze: C2 team; 2005 Tacen silver: C2 team)

name: Shaul Ladany
description: A member of the Jewish community of Beograd, Shaul Ladany was 8-years-old when he was sent to the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. Although he lost many members of his family, he and his parents survived until the liberation of the Camp. A 1972 article quoted him as saying “A ransom deal that the Americans attempted saved 2,000 Jews and I was one. I actually went into the gas chamber but was reprieved. God knows why”. Ladany started his athletic career as a marathon runner but in his mid-20s he switched to race walking and won the first of his 28 Israeli titles in 1963. He made his Olympic début in 1968 in the 50 km walk and returned as the sole male member of the Israeli athletics team in 1972. After completing his race in 19th place he returned to the village and went to bed. In the early hours of the next morning Latany was awakened by the screamed warning of the wrestling official, Yossef Gutfreund, and escaped the Black September terrorists by jumping from a balcony onto the lawn below. Ladany was the first man to alert the world as to what was happening in the Israeli dormitories and was one of only five Israeli team members to escape death at the hands of the terrorists. Ladany returned to competition later in 1972 when, against the wishes of the Israeli track and field authorities, he competed and won the world 100 km walking title in Switzerland. A specialist in ultra long distance walking, his world best for the 50 mile walk has stood for over thirty years, Ladany has continued to compete with considerable success at masters level into his 70s. Away from the world of athletics, Ladany was a professor of industrial engineering at Ben-Gurion University and an author of many scholarly books and scientific articles. In 1997 he published his autobiography, The Walk to the Olympics. In 2007 he received the Pierre de Coubertin Medal. Personal Best: 50kmW – 4-17:06 (1972).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Survived Nazi Concentration Camps (Bergen-Belsen concentration camp)

name: Denis Zimba
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 2002 Manchester BOX silver: lightweight -60 kg)

name: Bob Hughes
description: Personal Best: 20kmW – 1-33:08 (1968).

name: Mark Bedlington
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1987 Indianapolis SHO bronze: 50 m running target) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (1–2–0 1990 Auckland SHO silver: running target/pairs; 1994 Victoria SHO gold: running target/pairs, silver: running target)

name: Ngaire Lane
description: Ngaire Lane took up swimming as a schoolgirl, earned three New Zealand junior national titles in 1940, in the 50 and 100 yards freestyle, and set the first of her many national records in the 50 yards backstroke. She earned national senior titles in the 100 and 220 yards backstroke in 1944, the first two of 14 that she would win through 1949. During this time, she competed in several international tournaments, none of which were as prestigious at the 1948 Summer Olympics, where she represented New Zealand in the 100 metres backstroke. She came second in her round one heat, behind only Dutchwoman Ria van der Horst, but was eliminated in the semi-finals. She retired from active competition after the 1949 season and, by career, she was a secretary. Her granddaughter Gina Galloway competed in swimming at the 2018 Summer Youth Olympics.
special_notes: Grandmother of Gina Galloway

name: Li Yunfei
description: Men: 2001 World Championships (6); 2000 Four Continents Championships (11); 2001 Four Continents Championships (8).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (1–0–0 1999 Poprad Tatry FSK gold: singles)

name: Lajos Tóth
description: Lajos Tóth was a gymnast with Debreceni Torna Egylet (TE) from 1929, before joining Debreceni Postás in 1948. Tóth won the individual all-around national championship title three times (1935, 1937, 1939). Between 1934 and 1948, he won 22 different individual championships in Hungary, and from 1934-52 he earned 33 caps. During this time, Tóth competed at three Olympics. With the Hungarian team he finished seventh in 1936, third in 1948, and sixth in 1952. In 1934 he was a member of the fifth-place team at the World Championships, finishing fifth on the floor exercise and sixth in the vault. In 1935 he won the Universiade with the team and finished second in the individual all-around. From 1942 Tóth was an intern at the Hajdúszoboszló Tax Office, then returned to Debrecen, where he worked as a general re-settlement advisor. In 1948 he was general-secretary of Debreceni Postás, while from 1948-50 he was honorary chairman of Hajdú County and the Debrecen City Sports Committee. From 1952 he was head coach of Debreceni Postás, then the president of the Hajdú-Bihar County Gymnastics Association. He retired as head of the Debrecen City Tax Office.

name: Josef Hladky
description: Czech-born swimmer Josef Hladky defected to West Germany during the World Championships at Madrid in 1986. Earlier he had won one silver and three bronze medals at the European Championships representing Czechoslovakia. He participated at the 1992 Barcelona Summer Games representing his new homeland Germany. He was eliminated in the heats of the 200 IM. Hladky later added another bronze over 200 IM, and a gold medal, at the Short Course Europeans in 1991. In January 1998, Hladky took over the management as the sole shareholder of pool construction company Hildenbrand GmbH and from then concentrated on swimming pool construction.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Set a European Record in Short Course Swimming (100 m medley – 16 March 1991 - 21 November 1992: 54.66 (16 March 1991; Bonn, GER)) Listed in Olympians Who Set a World Record in Short Course Swimming (100 m medley – 16 May 1991 - 21 November 1992: 54.66 (16 May 1991; Bonn, GER)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (0–1–4 1981 Split SWM bronze: 200 m medley (competed for Czechoslovakia); 1983 Roma SWM bronze: 200 m medley and 400 m medley (competed for Czechoslovakia); 1985 Sofia SWM silver: 200 m medley (competed for Czechoslovakia); 1989 Bonn SWM bronze: 200 m medley (competed for West Germany)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Swimming Championships (25 m) (1–0–0 1991 Gelsenkirchen gold: 100 m medley)

name: Juhani Wahlsten
description: Juhani Wahlsten played ice hockey for Finland at the 1960, 1964, and 1968 Winter Olympics. He helped Finland win a silver medal at the 1962 European Championships. He also played at the World Championships in 1959, 1962, 1965, 1967, and 1969. He played for several teams in Finnish leagues but is best known for his time with Turun Palloseura (TPS). He also played for KalPa (Kalevan Pallo), Ilves, and HJK (Helsingin Jalkapalloklubi). After his playing career ended in 1971 Wahlsten became a coach. He coached TPS from 1971-72, then was with FC Barcelona. He returned to TPS from 1980-83, but later coached the Finnish U-20 team, and also coached HC Davos in 1987-88. Wahlsten was inducted into the Finnish Hockey Hall of Fame in 1986.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Ice Hockey Championships (0–1–0 1962 Colorado Springs and Denver silver)

name: Ismaël, Comte de Lesseps
description: Ismaël de Lesseps competed in sabre at the 1908 Olympics, alongside his brother, Bertrand de Lesseps. Another brother, Mathieu de Lesseps, competed in equestrian events at the 1900 Olympics. They were three of 17 children born to Ferdinand de Lesseps out of two different wives. Ferdinand de Lesseps was a French diplomat who later helped plan and develop the Suez Canal. All three brothers were also early French pioneers of aviation. A fourth brother, Jacques, who was not an Olympian, served in the 2nd Bombing Group of the French Service as a captain and pilot, and in August 1918 received the American Distinguished Service Cross for bravery. Ismaël de Lesseps became a career military officer, joining the 3e Régiment de Chasseurs in the early 1900s, eventually rising to the rank of captain. In January 1913 he was made a Chevalier de la Legion d’Honneur for services to France. In August 1914 he was mobilized with his regiment. De Lesseps was killed in action in Vigny, France in late September 1915.
special_notes: Brother of Bertrand, Comte de Lesseps Brother of Mathieu de Lesseps Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Comte (Count)) Listed in Olympians Who Were Killed or Missing in Action or Died as a Result of War (†30 September 1915. Killed in action during World War I.)

name: Dan Veatch
description: Dan Veatch swam for Princeton University. He was US champion in both backstrokes at the 1984 US Long-Course Nationals. In addition to his Olympic appearance Veatch swam for the US at the 1986 World Championships, winning gold in the medley relay, at the 1987 and 1989 Pan Pacific Championships, and at the 1991 Pan American Games. He won gold in the 200 back at the Pan Pacs in both 1987 and 1989, adding a medley relay gold in 1987. He won silver in the 200 back at the 1991 Pan Ams. Veatch later became an open water swimmer, competing in several events in California, and competed in masters swimming events. Openly gay, he won nine medals at the 1998 Gay Games. In 1996 he earned an MBA from U Cal Berkeley. He then worked as Chief Financial Officer (CFO) at Petkevich & Partners in the Bay Area from 2001-03, and then as CFO at GCA Advisors, a global economy company.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1991 La Habana SWI silver: 200 m backstroke) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Pan Pacific Swimming Championships (3–0–0 1987 Brisbane gold: 200 m backstroke and 4×100 m medley relay; 1989 Tokyo gold: 200 m backstroke) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Aquatics Championships (1–0–0 1986 Madrid SWI gold: 4×100 m medley relay)

description: Veterinary surgeon.

name: Jürgen Nolte
description: Sabre fencer Jürgen Nolte finished fourth, sixth and fifth with the (West) German sabre teams at the 1984 Los Angeles, 1988 Seoul, and 1992 Barcelona Olympics. Individually, he was eliminated in the quarter-finals in 1984 but was placed eighth in both 1988 and 1992. In 1989 he won a team silver at the World Championships and two bronze medals in 1990-91. Nolte won eight individual national titles between 1980 and 1990. Returning from the 1989 Worlds, Nolte survived the cash-landing of United Airlines Flight 232 at Sioux City following a catastrophic failure of its tail-mounted engine. By profession, Nolte became a sport and biology school teacher at Bonn-Tannenbusch.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–1–2 1989 Denver silver: sabre team (competed for West Germany); 1990 Lyon bronze: sabre team (competed for West Germany); 1991 Budapest bronze: sabre team (competed for Germany))

name: Ismael Ramzi
description: Ismael Ramzi took up diving as a student at Egyptian University (now Cairo University) and quickly found success at the national level, specializing in the springboard. He was studying there when he was selected to represented his country at the 1936 Berlin Olympics, where he placed 11th among 24 entrants. World War II interrupted his career, but he returned to competition after the conflict, this time representing the Egyptian Army. He was again selected for the Olympics in 1948, where he placed 15th overall in the springboard. He won at least one more national championship the following year, but was retired by the next edition of the Games. By career, he was a medical doctor.

name: Ernst Fivian
description: Ernst Fivian took up gymnastics at the age of 13 and joined the Swiss national team six years later, in 1950. He represented his country at the 1952 Helsinki Olympics, where he took home a silver medal with the team and had a best finish of joint-seventh (alongside Soviet Iosif Berdiyev) in the horse vault. After a period out of the limelight, he returned to a great triumph at the 1959 European Championships, winning the floor exercise and coming in third in the horse vault. He appeared in his second Olympics in 1960, finishing eight with the team and having a best placement of joint-7th in the floor exercise. The next year, he again took bronze in the horse vault at the Europeans, before being forced to retire due to Achilles’ tendon injuries.

name: Dong Ying
description: Dong Ying had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 2nd 1995 K4 500 m (with Xian Bangdi, Gao Beibei, and Zhang Qin).

name: Mário Dunlop
description: Mário Dunlop was a member of the silver medal winning team at the 1967 Pan American Games.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1967 Winnipeg VOL silver)

name: Eric Camerota
special_notes: Twin brother of Brett Camerota

name: Hartmut Losch
description: Discus thrower Hartmut Losch, the brother of hammer thrower Manfred Losch, participated in three consecutive Olympic Games from 1964-72. He had his best result in 1968, placing an unfortunate fourth. At the 1966 Europeans Losch won a silver medal, winning gold in 1969, and placing fifth in 1971. In East Germany he was national champion in 1966, and was runner-up in 1964-65, 1967-68, 1972, and 1974. Professionally Losch was an officer in the Nationale Volksarmee (National People’s Army). Within the Army he worked as a sports instructor at Army Club Potsdam. At the age of 53 years he died from a heart attack in 1997 during a jogging session in the forest. Personal Best: DT – 64.36 (1972).
special_notes: Brother of Manfred Losch Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (1–1–0 1966 Budapest silver: discus throw (competed for East Germany); 1969 Athina gold: discus throw (competed for East Germany))

name: Folmer Bonnén
description: Danish painter Folmer Bonnén went to the Zahrtmann School from 1906-08 and débuted in 1907 at the Artists’ Autumn Exhibition. In 1909 he co-founded the artist group De Tretten (The Thirteen). Beginning in 1918 he managed a private painting school. Bonnén painted with strong and bold colouring, later changing his palette in line with agitating for a national art. He experimented with fresco and invented a new technique in which casein colours were painted on the cement. During World War II, Bonnén agitated for a national art and worked for the Danish Nazi Party’s newspaper. He also performed as a tenor and wrote poetry. Danish sources give the title of the Olympic submitted work as “Tovtrækkende drenge” (“Tug-of-War Boys”), dated 1924.

name: Yelena Belova
description: Yelena Belova made her international début at the 1991 World Championships, where she won golds in both the relay and team event and was seventh in the 7.5 km. At the 1992 Winter Olympics, Belova medaled in both events in which she competed, winning bronzes in both the 7.5 km and relay. She also won silver at the 1992 World Championships in the team event, while at the 1993 World Championships Belova won bronzes in the 7.5 km and relay. After finishing her sporting career in 1994, Belova worked as a hotel administrator and in 2005 began working with the ice hockey club Metallurg Magnitogorsk.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Biathlon Championships (2–1–2 1991 Lahti gold: 3×7.5 km relay and team (competed for the Soviet Union); 1992 Novosibirsk silver: team (competed for the Commonwealth of Independent States); 1993 Borovets bronze: 7.5 km sprint and 4×7.5 km relay (competed for Russia)) Listed in Olympic Order Recipients (1997 (Silver))

name: Torchy Millar
description: Torchy Millar won bronze in the individual jumping at the 1971 Pan American Games.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–1–1 1971 Cali EQU gold: jumping team, bronze: jumping individual; 1983 Caracas EQU silver: jumping team)

name: Calisto da Costa
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-33:11 (2000).

name: Mike Pelliccia
description: Mike Pelliccia was the first non-Italian native to play for the Italian National team in basketball. He played for Pallacanestro Napoli, G.U.F. (Gruppi Universitari Fascisti) Roma and S.S. Lazio He competed at the Berlin Olympics where the Azzurri placed seventh. He also competed at the 1937 and 1939 European Championships, placing second and sixth, respectively. Pelliccia earned 15 caps, scoring 24 points.

name: Bashir Varayev
description: Bashir Varayev was one of the best half-middleweight judokas of the world at the end of the 1980s. During his career Varayev won the 1988 Olympic bronze, the 1987 World Championships silver, and bronze at the 1989 and 1991 World Championships. Varayev won the European title four times (1987-90), while taking bronze at the 1991 and 1992 European Championships. He also won gold at the 1990 Goodwill Games and was Soviet champion from 1986-88.
special_notes: Brother of Sharip Varayev

name: Andrius Šidlauskas
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Games (1–1–0 2015 Bakı SWI gold: 50 m breaststroke, silver: 100 m breaststroke)

name: Vitali Dzerbianiou
description: Vitali Dzerbianiou was a Belarusian weightlifter who competed as a bantamweight. Dzerbianiou was born in Mahilyow in 1976. Dzerbianiou won the silver medal at the 1996 World Junior Championships. Dzerbianiou became one of the best weightlifters in Europe, winning gold medals at four editions of the European Weightlifting Championships (2002–03, 2006, 2010). Dzerbianiou competed at three Summer Olympics. At the 2000 Sydney Olympics Dzerbianiou finished in seventh place. Dzerbianiou narrowly missed out on a medal at the 2004 Athina Olympics when he finished in fourth place. Dzerbianiou’s final Games were the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Despite producing a good lift in the snatch, Dzerbianiou did not give a valid lift in the clean & jerk. In 2004 Dzerbianiou was awarded with the Honored Master of Sports of the Republic of Belarus. Dzerbianiou retired from the sport in 2011 due to a chronic shoulder injury. He died in May 2022 at the age of 45. Derbenev had the following podium finishes at major championships: 3rd in the 2001 European Championships Bantamweight class (262.5 kg); 1st in the 2002 European Championships Bantamweight class (277.5 kg); 1st in the 2003 European Championships Bantamweight class (275.0 kg); 2nd in the 2004 European Championships Bantamweight class (280.0 kg); 3rd in the 2005 European Championships Bantamweight class (260.0 kg); 1st in the 2006 European Championships Bantamweight class (268.0 kg); 2nd in the 2007 European Championships Bantamweight class (266.0 kg).

name: Sharon Stouder
description: Fifteen-year-old Sharon Stouder from Glendora High School in California was the surprise swimmer of the 1964 Olympics. She was the unexpected winner of the 100m butterfly, defeating the highly favored Ada Kok, and depriving the Dutch girl of her world record in the bargain. In the 100m freestyle she nearly caused even a greater upset, finishing only 0.4 seconds down to the great Dawn Fraser. In taking the silver medal she became the second woman to break the one-minute barrier. She won two more gold medals in the relays, picking up world record shares in both events. Her other successes included a gold medal in the medley relay at the 1963 Pan-American Games and, at the 1964 AAU outdoor championships, she won the 100m freestyle and both butterfly events, bettering her own world record in the 200 fly. Stouder would later graduate from Stanford and became a member of the Stanford (1997) and International Swim (1972) Halls of Fame. In 1984 she was honored by Stanford by lighting the Olympic Torch at the Stanford Stadium for the soccer events that were held there.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (2–0–0 1963 São Paulo SWI gold: 4×100 m freestyle relay and 4×100 m medley relay) Listed in Olympians Who Set a World Record in Long Course Swimming (100 m butterfly – 16 October 1964 - 14 August 1965: 1:04.7 (16 October 1964; Tokyo, JPN); 200 m butterfly – 12 July 1964 - 15 August 1965: 2:28.1 (12 July 1964; Los Angeles, USA), 2:26.4 (2 August 1964; Palo Alto, USA); 4×100 m freestyle relay – 15 October 1964 - 19 August 1967: 4:03.8 (15 October 1964; Tokyo, JPN); 4×100 m medley relay – 18 October 1964 - 30 July 1967: 4:33.9 (18 October 1964; Tokyo, JPN))

name: Max Guilleaume
description: Max Guilleaume was a member of one of the wealthiest family of entrepreneurs in the city of Köln (Cologne). The family started in the rope, wire and cable industry, and became known worldwide by producing and laying the first overseas cable from Europe to America. In 1900 Max Guilleaume was ennobled to the hereditary nobility. He acquired the Calmuth estate and had it built into a prestigious country house (“Castle Calmuth”) by the architect Otto March, designer of the Olympic Stadium for the scheduled 1916 Berlin Games. In 1900, he participated at the Paris Olympics in the four-in-hand competition as an equestrian with an unknown result. He was open to all technical developments, which led to his becoming a pioneer in driving automobiles. He was a successful sailor with the British-built schooner “Clara” and competed, amongst others, in the Emperor’s Cup between Dover and the island of Helgoland. After the death of his wife Clara, he retreated from business and social activities and shot himself, committing suicide on a porch of his country house. It is believed that, in addition to depression after his wife’s death, financial problems in the aftermath of the economic depression led to his suicide.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Committed Suicide (Shot himself, committing suicide on a porch of his country house)

name: Peter Winters
special_notes: Brother of Carl Winters

name: Muhaisin Al-Jamaan
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–1–0 1986 Seoul FBL silver)

name: Todd Makler
description: Todd Makler grew up in suburban Philadelphia, where he attended the Friends Central School, and then the University of Pennsylvania, graduating in 1968. His father, Paul Makler, Sr., fenced for the United States at the 1952 Olympics, and his brother, Brooke Makler, fenced at the 1976 Olympics. Todd Makler represented Salle Csiszar and twice was NCAA sabre champion. He earned a medical degree from Pennsylvania in 1972, competing in the Olympics and training while pursuing his medical studies. Makler later practiced radiology in Philadelphia.
special_notes: Brother of Brooke Makler Son of Paul Makler, Sr.

name: Géza Hollósi
description: Géza Hollósi had the following finishes at major championships – 1959 World Championship: 79.0 kg. Freestyle (2nd); 1961 World Championship: 79.0 kg. Freestyle (2nd); 1965 World Championship: 87.0 kg. Freestyle (5th); 1966 European Championship: 87.0 kg. Freestyle (5th); 1968 European Championship: 87.0 kg. Freestyle (6th).

name: József Keresztessy
description: József Keresztessy was the grandson of József Keresztessy, who was the founder of the Hungarian sabre school. Keresztessy was a gymnast with NTE and a member of the Hungarian Gymnastic team at the 1912 Stockholm Olympics. After completing his career, Keresztessy became head coach of the women’s team of NTE, where several famous Hungarian female gymnast started their career, among them Ágnes Keleti. Kresztessy continued to compete for over 50 years in age-group competitions. After the disbandment of NTE, he emigrated to Canada in 1948.

name: Alexander Thieme
description: East German Sprinter Alexander Thieme reached the semifinals of the 100 at the 1976 Montréal Olympics, but did not qualify for the final. However, he won a silver medal in the sprint relay. At the 1977 World Cup he also came in second with the relay and fourth in 1979. At the 1978 Europeans he was again second with the relay. In 1975 and 1977 Thieme won the European Cup and in 1979 he placed second, both times in the 4x100 relay. He trained as an air-conditioning technologist and later became a construction entrepreneur. After German reunification he took over the construction company of his family in Jahnsdorf / Erzgebirge. Personal Best: 100 – 10.22 (1977).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (0–1–0 1978 Praha silver: 4×100 m relay)

name: Sunday Bada
description: Sunday Bada was a top Nigerian one-lap runner in the 1990s. Bada competed at three Olympics, originally winning a silver medal in the 2000 4×400 relay, but his Nigerian team was moved up to a gold medal after the disqualification of the United States’ team because of doping positives on two members (Jerome Young and Antonio Pettigrew). His biggest individual title was winning the 1997 World Indoor Championship over 400 metres, after having placed second in that event in 1993 and 1995. He twice made the finals at the World Athletics Championships in the 400, placing fifth in 1993 and eighth in 1997. At the 1997 World Championships, he helped Nigeria win a bronze medal in the 4×400. Bada also won the 1997 All-African Games 200 metres, the 1992 World Cup 400 metres, and won a bronze medal in the 400 at the 1994 Commonwealth Games. He was world-ranked eighth in 1993 and ninth in 1995 in the 400 metres. After his retirement from competition, he became technical director of the Athletics Federation of Nigeria. Personal Bests: 200 – 20.28 (1995); 400 – 44.63 (1993).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (0–0–1 1995 Göteborg bronze: 4×400 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Indoor Championships (1–2–0 1993 Toronto silver: 400 m; 1995 Barcelona silver: 400 m; 1997 Paris gold: 400 m) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1994 Victoria ATH bronze: 400 m)
